After the retail bloodletting unleashed by Macy's (M) quarterly report, other chains that have been performing better, such as Wal-Mart (WMT) and Home Depot (HD), could offer an alternative to the current, apocalyptic narrative with their own reports. Meanwhile,…

Acorda Therapeutics (ACOR) will put four programs to treat Parkinson's, migraines and multiple sclerosis on the back burner to deal with the potential loss of funding wrought by the planned expiration of exclusive sales rights for its multiple sclerosis drug Ampyra in July 2018, CEO Ron Cohen said.Though Acorda is appealing the invalidation of four patents protecting Ampyra, the midcap biotech is planning to trim $50 million per year from its expenses. Cohen says the company invests 40% of its revenue into research and development.In the meantime, Acorda will focus on two Parkinson's drugs — the furthest along in its pipeline of six. Inbrija, also known as CVT-301, is an inhaled version of L-DOPA, a key treatment for Parkinson's. Tozadenant can be added to treatment regimens to extend the amount of time users have muscle control.Still, Cohen told Investor's Business Daily, those two drugs will do "very little" to curb the loss of Ampyra exclusivity. In 2016, Ampyra brought in $493 million in sales. Acorda is planning to file an application with the FDA for Inbrija by the end of June and expects a 10-month review."Ampyra is an over $500 million net revenue stream now and even Inbrija is approved in 2018 and we launch it, it's not going to be anywhere close to $500 million in the first year," he said. "It takes time in a launch to ramp up as more and more patients are aware of it and doctors prescribe it."Data on Inbrija have been strong, Cohen said. Inhaling L-DOPA, as opposed to taking a pill, is a much faster method of delivery, he said. In clinical trials, Inbrija began working as early as 10 minutes relative to the placebo. It hasn't been shown to cause any damage to the lungs.Swallowing pills tends to be a slower method of delivery because it requires digestion. Inhaled drugs have fewer barriers to pass to begin working, he said. In another study, patients on L-DOPA were found to still have unabsorbed pills in their stomachs two hours after taking them.IBD'S TAKE: Acorda isn't the only company suffering troubles with multiple sclerosis drugs. Biogen's (BIIB) MS franchise is facing competition from Roche (RHHBY), Novartis (NVS) and Sanofi (SNY). Head to IBD's Technology page for a deeper dive on why Biogen's takeover prospects are now close to nil.But it's a balancing act because too many drugs can cause uncontrolled movements called dyskinesia."They either have too little or they have too much," he said. "And because trying to take more pills can screw up their whole regimen, that's also not a good solution."Acorda is also working on tozadenant, which Cohen called the first new mechanism for Parkinson's in more than 20 years. Patients on multiple Parkinson's regimens can add tozadenant to increase the amount of time they have muscle control. In trials, the drug extended "on periods" by an hour.But, to focus on Inbreja and tozadenant, drugs in Parkinson's, migraine and multiple sclerosis will have to take a back seat, be partnered on or licensed out, Cohen said. A fourth drug, a recently acquired anti-inflammatory, was always planned to be licensed as it's not in Acorda's neurological sweet spot.Eventually, Cohen says, he'd like to restart those programs. The migraine and heart failure drugs, though, were already slated for the back burner because of, respectively, side effects in the liver and lungs."In essence, this is a partial, tactical retreat so we can come back with success and ramp up our investments in the earlier-stage products," he said. "It may be along the way we find it necessary to partner those programs with some other companies."RELATED:Acorda Trims 20% Of Workforce But Looming Cuts Could Be DeeperAcorda, Forward, Biogen Fall On Multiple Sclerosis Drug FightAcorda, Forward Stocks Plunge On Multiple Sclerosis Court Rulings

Hillary Clinton has granted her first public interview since losing the election. It came on April 6 at the Women in the World Summit, organized by leftist editor Tina Brown. Clinton was introduced by comedian Samantha Bee. On cue, as expected, she gushed: "You deserve to hear it 100 times — it should have been you."The assignment to interview Clinton fell to New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof. He later wrote a column on his Hillary chat, beginning by saying: "In the most wrenching, humiliating way possible, Hillary Clinton has been liberated. She is now out of the woods again, and speaking her mind."And why not? The path is marked by rose petals dutifully placed by her equally humiliated legions in the press.It was "humiliating" to lose to Donald Trump — that lout. Clinton was the anointed one, and as the press told us, she was the most qualified presidential applicant since Thomas Jefferson. So the feminists at this conference wanted to know: Why do Americans hate women so deeply? What the hell is wrong with those self-hating white Republican women?This was the kind of challenging "question" Kristof lobbed at Clinton: "This is a women's empowerment conference, so I have to ask. You know, fundamentally, a man who bragged about sexual assault won the election and won 53% of the white women's vote. How is it that in the 21st century — and what does it say about the challenges that one faces in women's empowerment — that in effect, misogyny won with a lot of women voters?"Clinton loved the question. It's the kind of softball she's been served her entire career. "Certainly, misogyny played a role," she declared. "I mean, that just has to be admitted." She and Kristof mulled over what he called "abundant social science research" that says we admire men for being ambitious and successful but find women "less likable" when they are powerful.So here we are, five months after the election, and the best analysis these people can muster sounds exactly like ... the last weekend of the campaign. Then-President Barack Obama used this argument as his closer: Don't be a sexist! He said: "I want you to think about it because she is so much better qualified than the other guy. She has conducted herself so much better in public life than the other guy."Clinton complained that when she left the State Department, her approval rating was 64% or 65%, but "by the time they finished with me, I was Typhoid Mary." "They" meant Trump and the conservative media. Never would this woman ever concede that the more the public saw and heard her, the less it liked her. In an added note of self-pity, she added: "Poor Mary. She didn't deserve it either."The woman who might have been our commander in chief standing up to Russia, Iran, North Korea and the Islamic State group complained about being called names, drawing fervent applause. She explained that the aim of anti-Clinton bullying was "to crush your spirit, to make you feel inadequate, to make you doubt yourself. And I just refused to do that, and that infuriated them even more."Nowhere in this dialogue, and nowhere in the Kristof column that followed, did they even briefly entertain the notion that misogyny could define the Clintons. She can complain about Trump's "targeting of women" but can't imagine that anyone could say the same for her husband. Let us not forget that Kristof and his newspaper thought Juanita Broaddrick's absolutely believable accusation of Bill Clinton raping her was "toxic waste."Hillary Clinton never allows an interviewer who would ask her about her role leading the Bimbo-Bashing Patrol to destroy the reputations of her husband's victims. No one is allowed to ask whether Broaddrick was lying when she said that after the alleged assault, Hillary Clinton gripped her hand firmly and thanked her for her support, and suggested that she stay quiet.They certainly refuse to contemplate that women could vote for Trump because Clinton stood passionately on the libertine left, supporting abortion on demand, every LGBT dictate and the erosion of religious liberty. It is reported that half of the aborted babies are girls. Couldn't that be "misogyny"?If only someone at these media-elite confabs would ask how a majority of women can be smeared as hating themselves if they don't check every radical-feminist box.

The late-night comics turned their liberal rage on Ivanka Trump after she granted an interview on April 5 to "CBS This Morning" co-host Gayle King.It was an interesting choice for a television interview considering King would clearly be hostile. She partied with Oprah and the Obamas in the White House after President Obama's first inauguration. Need one question her political leanings?It should have come as no surprise when King asked whether Ivanka was "complicit" in her father's administration, as if President Trump's presidency should be considered illegal and morally bankrupt.King was borrowing from a nasty "Saturday Night Live" skit that went viral on the left, of a fake Ivanka Trump perfume ad with the tagline "Complicit: the fragrance for the woman who could stop all of this but won't."The president's daughter responded like a politician, saying, "If being complicit means wanting to be a force for good and wanting to make a positive impact, then I'm complicit."Hours later, CBS late-night host Stephen Colbert pulled out a dictionary and read the illegal/wrongdoing definition of "complicit" and mocked Trump, saying her response was like saying, "If being a Nazi means fighting for civil rights, then yeah, I'm a huge Nazi!"Mocking the quote where Trump's lawyer said she would be her father's "eyes and ears" in the White House, feminist TBS host Samantha Bee cracked that the first daughter will be "spending a lot of time staring at her own boobies."King channeled all the liberal outrage that Trump should be like a younger version of Hillary Clinton inside the White House, stopping everything that liberals don't like. She cited anonymous "critics" — i.e., the people she'd just spoken with down the hall at the water cooler — bemoaning her failure to foil the conservatives.She said: "You also talk about the critics, and you have a couple who say, 'Why isn't Ivanka speaking out? Where is she on Planned Parenthood? Where is she on gay rights? Where is she on the rights of women? Where is she on climate change?' And it's like you're being held personally accountable for not speaking up. What do you say to your critics?"Trump naturally answered that just because she's not denouncing her father in public doesn't mean she can't wield her liberal influence inside the family. But obviously, the government is not moving in the direction of "New York values" right now, so that clearly wasn't good enough.Now compare: The day before CBS launched into Trump, it offered a typically fawning interview to Chelsea Clinton. No one has ever asked Chelsea Dearest whether she was "complicit" in her father's sexual offenses, or "complicit" in her family's corrupt foundation, even though she's a vice chair. Put the emphasis on "vice."Instead, America witnessed all the mandatory mewling over her wonderfulness. Will she run for president? King couldn't curb her enthusiasm. She said: "Is there anybody else in the Clinton household thinking about running? And by anybody, I mean you. You could take your book on the road while you're campaigning with 'Get Informed, Get Inspired, Get Going.' I feel like déjà vu with your mom all over again. Are you running? Are you running? Are you running?"Earth to CBS: The country just said no to a Clinton dynasty.Co-host Norah O'Donnell asked: "What do you think about what Russia did during the campaign? ... Do you think they had any role in your mother's defeat — Russian influence?" They simply will not accept that their candidate lost to him because America didn't want her.The double standard on first daughters and their parents never ends. One gets powder puffs and cotton candy. The other gets a sledgehammer.One hopes there will be a learning moment here for Ivanka Trump. Sometimes the best response to a media request is to just say no.RELATED:Trump News & Tweets

The L-shape pattern has been discussed in this column regularly over the past several years. It features a sharp fall, a feeble rebound attempt, and a clear entry point for those courageous enough to act on the speculation that a former winner has more room to drop in price. IBD's research on this relatively new discovery of investor behavior, first noted by…

On April 5, The New York Times published an op-ed by retired Army Gen. Stanley McChrystal headlined "Save PBS. It Makes Us Safer." McChrystal now runs a big lobbying firm, so that may be why he cares so much — he's a gun for hire.So how does the general think PBS makes us safer? And from what are we safer? The answer: commercialism. Parents like his son and daughter-in-law "are busy in the morning and busy at night," he says. "They want to protect their children from over-commercialized content."This argument is bizarre — actually, let's call it what it is: disingenuous — at a time when "Sesame Street," which was used to illustrate this article online, of course, is now an HBO property."Sesame Street" is the embodiment of the need for public funding? This is nonsense. Big Bird generates a fortune in the private sector. When you search "Sesame Street" under "all departments" on the Amazon website, it produces 39,276 results.McChrystal concluded that the people defunding PBS are waging a war on civil society, asking, "Why then would we degrade or destroy an institution that binds us together?"Some lobbyists will say anything. We hope he's well-compensated for writing those words. He's also featured in a video made by the lobbying group America's Public Television Stations claiming that public media "gets to the center" and is the "adult in the room" of the news business.So what is it that binds us together anyway? Justin Haskins reports at TheBlaze that the PBS LearningMedia website has a lesson plan for grades nine through 12 titled "Dying to be a Martyr." The lesson "investigates conflict in the Middle East using interviews with young would-be suicide bombers." Video interviews shown in the class were done in 2004.First, there's 18-year-old Mohanned Abu Tayyoun, a Palestinian "who entered Israel carrying a bag of explosives with the intention of carrying out a suicide bombing." But he wavered and "returned home without carrying out the mission."Tayyoun is interviewed from a jail cell in Israel about why he wanted to be a suicide bomber. He said: "Martyrdom leads us to God. I don't want this life. When you become a martyr, your prize for carrying out the operation is going to heaven. ... We Palestinians prefer to die, just kill ourselves, rather than live this worthless life. Our life's worthless. We are hollow bodies living a pointless life. Israelis enjoy their life. They go out at night. They have cafes and nightclubs. They travel all over the world. They go to America and Britain. We can't even leave Palestine."Teachers are told: "Check for understanding by asking students to respond to the focus question. (Mohanned feels he would rather die and by a martyr than live his life, sees his life as hollow — in contrast he sees Israelis as happy, going out, having fun, traveling.) Ask your students why Mohanned may feel that way."In other words, feel his pain. We'd rather ask why PBS feels it can abuse the American taxpayer this way.There's more. Students watch 25-year-old Majdi Amer, who built a bomb and prepared a suicide bomber for a bus attack in Haifa, Israel, "that killed 17 people and wounded 50" in March 2003.Amer is asked why he believes it's acceptable to kill women and children. He says: "If the Israelis kill a child in Gaza, I'm ready to kill one in Tel Aviv. If they destroy houses in Gaza, I'll do it in Tel Aviv. If they give me security in my land, then there's no problem."Teachers are then tasked to explore "how Majdi and Mohanned's opinions differ from one another, even though they are both Palestinians involved in suicide bombing plots." The lesson planners at PBS have no instructions to denounce suicide bombing or radical Islam. None.The website lists JPMorgan Chase and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting as the funders. That means you are paying for this.Dear General McChrystal: PBS isn't "making us safer" by promoting suicide bombers like the ones that killed your soldiers in Afghanistan.RELATED:Big Bird Is Rich, So Why Does He Need Taxpayer Money?

Shares of computing and graphics chip maker Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) plummeted after receiving a stock downgrade on Tuesday, a day after posting in-line results for the first quarter.Meanwhile, semiconductor equipment maker KLA-Tencor (KLAC) scored a price-target increase.Investment bank Macquarie Group cut its rating on AMD to underperform from neutral and lowered its price target to 10 from 14.AMD plunged 24.4% to 10.30 on the stock market today, the lowest since late January."While the company appears to be making progress with its new Ryzen product, Q1 results clearly fell short of high expectations the stock was reflecting," Macquarie analyst Srini Pajjuri said in a report.AMD's first-quarter report late Monday underwhelmed. The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company lost 4 cents a share excluding items, vs. a year-earlier loss of 12 cents a share, on sales of $984 million, up 18%, for the March quarter."AMD's new products are beginning to accelerate growth, but perhaps without all the gross margin benefits we had hoped for," Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Christopher Rolland said in a report. "The (roughly) 30% ramp in shares over the last 3 months required a near perfect quarter, but results fell a bit short."IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks features eight chip industry players, including Lam Research and Advanced Energy Industries.Rolland rates AMD as neutral with a price target of 12.Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh was upbeat on AMD's results. He reiterated his buy rating and raised his price target on the stock to 14 from 13.AMD guided above consensus estimates for the current quarter at break even on sales of $1.15 billion, up 12%. Analysts were modeling for AMD to lose a penny a share on sales of $1.12 billion in the June quarter.Needham reiterated its strong buy rating on KLA-Tencor and upped its price target to 120 from 105, after last week's earnings report.KLA-Tencor stock rose 0.55% to 99.72."We like KLAC's better growth trajectory vs. peers over the next few quarters, the new product cycles (Gen 5, mask inspection, unannounced 3D Nand tool), industry-leading margins, and a discounted multiple relative to historical levels," Needham said in a report.Elsewhere in the semiconductor equipment sector, Advanced Energy Industries (AEIS) fell 0.15% to 73.95 after trading as low as 74.34 intraday.Late Monday, Advanced Energy Industries beat Wall Street's estimates for the March quarter and guided higher for earnings and revenue in the June quarter.The company's Q1 results and Q2 guidance were good, but the magnitude of the beat-and-raise report was lower than expected after the very strong reports from peers Lam Research (LRCX) and MKS Instruments (MKSI) over the past two weeks, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Weston Twigg said in a report.RELATED:Chipmaker AMD Down Late On In-Line Q1 ResultsQualcomm Gets More Price-Target Cuts; Silicon Motion, Ichor HikedIntel Tumbles On Just-Shy Sales, But These 3 Chip Plays Beat

Cohu (COHU) saw its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating rise to 99 Monday, up from 93 the day before.The upgrade means the stock currently tops 99% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. Winning stocks often have a 95 or higher grade in the early stages of a new price run.Cohu is not currently near a proper buy point. See if the stock goes on to form a new base and offer a new buying opportunity. Be aware that it is a thinly traded stock, with average daily dollar volume under $8 million.One weak spot is the company's 79 EPS Rating, which tracks quarterly and annual earnings-per-share growth. Look for that to improve to 80 or better to show it's in the top 20% of all stocks.Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A shows heavy buying by institutional investors over the last 13 weeks.In Q1, the company posted 483% earnings growth. It has now posted accelerating EPS gains for three consecutive quarters. Top line growth climbed 23%, up from 11% in the prior report. That marks three consecutive reports with rising growth.Cohu earns the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group. Applied Materials (AMAT) and ASML (ASML) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?

Stocks erased losses at the open and were mixed early Thursday, as markets in Europe lagged and investors kept a wary eye on oil prices.The Dow Jones industrial average rose less than 0.1%, as Nike (NKE) fell 0.5% and JPMorgan (JPM) rose 0.5%. The S&P 500 also was up a fraction but the Nasdaq fell a fraction.Oil moved to center stage on Wednesday, with the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate collapsing more than 5%, to $50.28 per barrel — its lowest level since mid-December — after the Energy Information Administration reported U.S. inventories rose to record levels for a ninth straight week. The loss shook oil out of its three-month trading range, making oil stocks nine of the S&P 500's 10 largest decliners for the day.Oil trimmed its early losses on the stock market today, down just over 1% to $49.63 per barrel. The dollar was mixed, up against the yen, down vs. the euro. The 10-year yield was up 2 basis points to 2.58%.Chevron (CVX) slipped 0.4%, Exxon Mobil (XOM) sagged 0.6% on the Dow.Cosmetics maker e.l.f. Beauty (ELF) surged 17% after strong fourth-quarter results and full-year estimates swept past analyst estimates. Gross margins jumped to 59% from 54% a year earlier. Shares are still in a consolidation and about 75% above their September IPO price.Chipmaker Semtech (SMTC) was up 2% after paring gains. A 118% earnings increase and an 18% advance in revenue topped analysts' Q4 targets, and first-quarter sales and earnings guidance was also stronger than expected.  Semtech is in a buy range on a rebound from its 10-week moving average.China-based social networking site Momo (MOMO) pulled back more than 4%. The IBD 50 stock is still extended well above a 23.96 cup-with-handle buy point.Bankrate (RATE) dived 6% after a 14% earnings gain and a 21% increase in revenue missed analyst forecasts. First-quarter and full-year revenue guidance was above the consensus targets. The stock has been forming a cup-with-handle base but has undercut the handle.Horizon Global (HZN), a maker of towing and trailer accessories, dived 15% at the open. The company, which spun off from diversified operator Trimas (TRS) in 2015, reported a 51% increase in fourth-quarter revenue, but a much deeper-than-forecast loss and issued mixed guidance for the full year. The stock slid further below its 200-day line.U.S. employers announced 36,957 layoffs in February, according to consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas, down 19% from the number of job cuts announced in January, and 40% below the layoffs announced a year earlier. Retailers were the largest portion of the picture, trimming 11,889 workers. Energy was next in line, with 5,930 layoffs.Initial unemployment claims rose to 243,000 in the week ended March 4, the Labor Department reported, up from the prior week's 223,000 claims and above consensus projections for 238,000 new claims.The Labor Department also reported that price of imports rose 0.2% in February, down from a 0.4% gain in January and in line with expectations. Export prices gained 0.3%, up from a 0.1% price gain in January and above forecasts for a 0.2% increase.Markets in Europe kept their early losses in afternoon trade: the FTSE 100 in London lagged 0.7%, while Frankfurt's DAX dropped 0.2% and the CAC 40 in Paris was off 0.3%.RELATED:Homebuilder Stocks Move Close To A Leadership Role

Ulta Beauty's (ULTA) estimate-beating results and double-digit same-store sales make it a retail outlier amid a landscape beset with weak traffic and comparable sales declines. But can it keep up this pace?When the specialty beauty retailer reports late Thursday, Wall Street expects 26% profit growth to $2.13 a share on 21.5% revenue gains to $1.54 billion.Shares fell 2.1% to 269.92 in the stock market today, moving back below a 274.09 buy point and testing its 50-day moving average for the first time in three months. The stock has been rising just above or below the entry area for the past several weeks.Other retailers — including Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Target (TGT) — have disappointed investors. Amazon.com (AMZN) looms ever larger as the reason for many retail woes.But the off-price, home improvement and specialty beauty sectors frequently get call-outs for eluding Amazon's tentacles.And one indicator of Ulta's holiday-quarter performance may come from rival Sephora, whose parent company LVMH reported results in late January."We're optimistic on the opportunity for sustained growth at ULTA, as LVMH reported further (double-digit) growth in revenue and profit at Sephora, driven by market share gains in all regions," wrote Cowen analyst Oliver Chen in late January, adding that strong shopper demand for specialty beauty products "bodes well for Ulta."In fact, he appears to prefer it over Sephora, which only carries high-end "prestige" brands. Ulta carries mass brands such as Revlon (REV), Maybelline and NYX in addition to upscale products from the likes of Urban Decay Cosmetics and Nars."While we acknowledge ULTA and Sephora overlap on some brands, we continue to like ULTA's exposure to a wider demographic with a broad spectrum of brands from mass to prestige."IBD'S TAKE: What's holding back Amazon and other e-commerce pure plays from eating into Sephora and Ulta's market share? There are several reasons why Amazon has been powerless against beauty stores. But even strong reports don't always provide Ulta shares with an immediate post-earnings boost. Its last two quarterly disclosures have been accompanied by declines before shares picked up steam again.E.l.f. Beauty (ELF) reports Q4 results Wednesday after the closing bell. The value-cosmetics brand's stock fell 2.9% to 25.92 on Tuesday. E.l.f. came public last September at 17 a share, rising as high as 32.54 on Nov. 29, but has struggled since then.RELATED:Ulta Beauty Forms New Holding Company For 'More Efficient' StructureMacy's, Costco, Kohl's And Other Retailers Are Getting SlammedE.l.f. Beauty CEO Amin On Social Cosmetics And The Ageless Beauty Boom

E.l.f. Beauty (ELF) and Semtech (SMTC) reported better-than-expected earnings late Wednesday, while Camping World (CWH) gave mixed results and men's apparel retailer Tailored Brands (TLRD) missed on the top and bottom lines.E.l.f. Beauty, which sells value cosmetics at various stores as well as few of its own locations, earned 19 cents a share excluding items, beating views by five cents. Sales rose 17% to $76.4 million, beating the consensus for $74.5 million. For 2017, e.l.f. sees EPS of 40-43 cents and sales of $285 million to $291 million, above Wall Street forecasts for 37 cents and $281 million.Shares of e.l.f. shot up 12.7% to 28.51 in late trading. During the regular session, e.l.f. fell 3.3% to 25.30 on the stock market today, its fifth straight losing session. E.l.f. came public at 17 a share in late September, nearing doubling over the next two months before beginning a downturn.Cosmetics and beauty products retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reports after the market close Thursday. Ulta rose 2.1% to 275.47 on Wednesday, retaking a 274.09 buy point.Fabless chipmaker Semtech earned 37 cents a share, up 118% vs. a year earlier and two cents above estimates. Non-GAAP sales climbed 20% to $141.18 million vs. views for $138.4 million. It was the fifth straight quarter of improving year-over-year changes for both EPS and revenue.Semtech rose 5.5% to 36.20 in late trading. Semtech closed up 2.4% to 34.30 after finding support at its rising 50-day line. The stock could surpass its recent peak of 36.15, the best since mid-2013.Camping World earned 14 cents a share, beating the consensus for 9 cents. But sales of $670 million, though up 3.5%, fell short of views for $678 million.Shares fell 5% to 33.70 in late trade, threatening to undercut a recent 34.39 buy point. During the regular session, Camping World rose 0.7% to 35.49.Camping World came public at 22 a share in early October.Tailored Brands, parent of Jos. A. Bank and Men's Wearhouse men's apparel chains, reported a Q4 loss of 19 cents a share vs. views for a 12-cent loss. Revenue fell 3.9% to $793.3 million, short of forecasts for $811 million.Tailored Brands shares crashed 27.3% to 17 late after closing up 1.1% to 23.37.

MKS Instruments (MKSI) received two price-target hikes from Wall Street analysts on Friday in the wake of the chip gear maker's better-than-expected first-quarter results and raised guidance. MKS stock fell 1.45% to 78.25 on the stock market today, ending a nine-session winning streak. On Thursday, MKS shares leapt 5.4% to 79.40 on its first-quarter report. MKS hit a record high of 81 in intraday…

X The first-quarter earnings season was in full swing on Thursday, with results coming after the market close from a host of notable tech firms.Among those reporting were chipmakers Intel (INTC), Apple (AAPL) iPhone component supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Microsemi (MSCC), as well as chip gear supplier KLA-Tencor (KLAC) and action-camera maker GoPro (GPRO).Intel earned 66 cents per share on sales of $14.8 billion in the first quarter, compared with 54 cents and $13.8 billion in the year-ago quarter. Analysts had expected earnings of 65 cents a share on sales of $14.8 billion. Intel's sales miss was due to weakness in its data center market, which has been a growth area.Intel sees Q2 adjusted EPS of 68 cents on revenue of $14.4 billion, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Wall Street was modeling for EPS of 64 cents and sales of $14.34 billion.Intel also raised its share buyback program.Intel shares tumbled nearly 4% in after-hours action. Shares closed up 1.4% to 37.43 on the stock market today, their ninth straight gain. Intel has a potential buy point of 38.55.Skyworks, an Apple chip supplier, earned $1.45 per share excluding items on sales of $851.7 million in its fiscal second quarter, compared with $1.25 and $775.1 million in the year-ago period. Analysts expected earnings of $1.40 a share on sales of $840.4 million in the March quarter.Skyworks stock sank 3% in after-hours trading. Shares closed up 1.1% to 104.10, at their best levels since July 2015.Microsemi earned 91 cents per share excluding items on sales of $442.9 million in its fiscal Q2, compared with 67 cents and $444.3 million a year earlier. Analysts were expecting earnings of 91 cents a share on sales of $439.8 million.Microsemi was up a fraction in late trading. The stock closed 0.3% higher at 49.14, trading between its 50-day and 200-day lines.KLA-Tencor earned $1.62 per share excluding items on sales of $914 million in its fiscal third quarter, compared with $1.15 and $712.4 million a year earlier. Analysts were expecting earnings of $1.55 a share on sales of $895.7 million.KLA-Tencor retreated 5% in late trading. The stock rose 2.8% to a new all-time high of 104.22 in the regular session.Chip-gear stocks in particular have been market leaders. Teradyne (TER) and Ultra Clean Holdings (UCTT) soared Thursday on their late Wednesday earnings reports.GoPro lost 44 cents per share excluding items on sales of $218.6 million in the first quarter, compared with a year-earlier loss of 63 cents on sales of $183.5 million. Analysts expected GoPro to lose 45 cents a share on sales of $207.9 million.GoPro sees Q2 revenue of $270 million, based on the midpoint of its guidance, vs. views of $244.4 million.GoPro shares initially rose sharply late, but reversed to trade down about 1%. GoPro closed the regular session down 2.2% to 8.94. The stock has been moving sideways near recent lows for several months.RELATED:Microsoft Beats Earnings Views, Misses On Sales In March QuarterGoogle Earnings, Revenue Blow Past EstimatesAmazon Beats On Top And Bottom Line, Stock JumpsWestern Digital Earnings Beat EstimatesStarbucks Profit Meets, But Sales, Comps Miss

Atlassian (TEAM) and Fortinet (FTNT) reported strong quarterly numbers, amid a slew of tech companies offering results late Thursday.Business software provider Atlassian after the market close Thursday reported fiscal Q3 adjusted earnings of 8 cents a share on revenue of $159.9 million for its fiscal third quarter ended March 31, compared with adjusted earnings of 7 cents on sales of $118 million in the year-ago quarter. The consensus estimate on Atlassian was EPS of 6 cents and revenue of $156.7 million.The company sees Q4 adjusted EPS of 8 cents, a penny above consensus, on revenue of $170 million-$172 million, with the midpoint in line with consensus for $171.1 million.Atlassian stock was quiet in after-hours trading on the stock market today but closed up 2% at 33.47.In other late earnings news, cybersecurity software provider Fortinet reported adjusted earnings of 17 cents a share on revenue of $340.6 million million for the first quarter, compared with adjusted earnings of 15 cents and revenue of $284.6 million in the year-ago quarter. Billings grew 22% to $403.3 million. Analysts were expecting EPS of 15 cents on revenue of $334.4 million. But shares sank 8.5% late to 37.00.RELATED:Amazon Beats On Top And Bottom Line, Stock Jumps Google Earnings, Revenue Blow Past EstimatesIntel Falls On Just-Shy Sales, But These 3 Chip Plays BeatMicrosoft Beats Earnings Views, Misses On Sales In March Quarter Western Digital Quarterly Earnings Beat EstimatesBefore the market open Thursday, chip-equipment maker Entegris (ENTG) reported adjusted earnings of 28 cents per share, up 65% year over year and beating the consensus estimate of 25 cents, on revenue of $317.4 million, up 19% and beating the consensus of $305 million. Entegris stock closed up 3.7% at 25.40.Meanwhile, China education company TAL Education (TAL) before the open reported adjusted earnings of 47 cents per American Depositary Share, up 104% year over year on revenue of $316.3 million, up 81%, for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Feb. 28. TAL stock finished 2.9% higher at 119.53.

Shares of China-based language-training and test-preparation services provider New Oriental Education (EDU) pulled back Monday after  on strong fiscal Q3 results, though guidance was cautious. Shares hit a record high but then reversed.Estimates: Fiscal Q3 EPS to increase 32%, to 41 cents, as revenue grows 21%, to $419.7 million.Results: EPS of 48 cents on revenue of $437.8 million. Total student enrollment increased 5.9% to 799,700. The number of schools and learning centers climbed by 14 from the prior quarters and by 76 from a year ago."We continued to make great progress in increasing operational efficiency, improving utilization of facilities and enhancing cost control in the quarter," said CFO Stephen Zhihui Yang in a statement. "Operating margin increased 90 basis points and net margin increased 140 basis points year-over-year. The continued strong bottom-line performance demonstrates the result of our consistent effort in creating sustainable long-term value for our customers and shareholders."Outlook: Fiscal Q4 revenue of $465.1 million-$479.9 million, with the midpoint slightly below consensus for $473.6 million.Stock: Shares initially jumped to a record 64.37 on the stock market today, topping a profit-taking sell threshold of 64.18 after breaking out last month. New Oriental Education fell as low as 61.77 to close exactly unchanged at 62.81Chinese peer Tal Education (TAL), which reports Thursday, 1.9% at 112.77, setting an all-time best. Tarena International (TEDU), a provider of professional education services, fell 0.6% to 18.60.New Oriental stock has rebounded since December, when Reuters reported that former New Oriental employees accused the company of helping students engage in college application fraud. But fiscal Q2 results in January showed a 56% jump in enrollment.

Eli Lake at Bloomberg News reported on April 3 that President Trump's lawyers discovered it was former President Obama's national security adviser Susan Rice who allegedly "requested the identities of U.S. persons in raw intelligence reports on dozens of occasions that connect to the Donald Trump transition and campaign."Susan Rice at the center of another scandal? Yes, and she's lying about it on TV again. On "PBS NewsHour" on March 22, anchor Judy Woodruff introduced the interview by telling viewers she asked Rice about whether Trump and his transition officials "may have been swept up in surveillance of foreigners at the end of the Obama administration."Rice protested: "I know nothing about this. I was surprised to see reports from Chairman Nunes on that count today." The Obama appointees were supposed to be smart, and yet they always say they didn't know anything.The PBS interview came about because the Washington Post allowed Rice to make a transparently hypocritical argument about truth twisting on its op-ed page that day. A preposterous promotional email headline read: "Susan Rice: When the White House twists the truth, we are all less safe. The actions of America's allies — and enemies — depend on our perceived credibility."On Sept. 16, 2012 — five days after radical Islamic terrorists killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya — Susan Rice lied through her teeth on five Sunday news programs that this preplanned attack with rocket launchers was somehow a "spontaneous reaction" to a "hateful and offensive video" on YouTube. Then, like many liars, she had the audacity in 2014 to declare on "Meet the Press," "What I said to you that morning, and what I did every day since, was to share the best information that we had at the time."Everyone knows that is patently false. Evidence flowed in that she and the president and then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton knew it was a terrorist attack. But everyone claimed otherwise for more than a week. They had an election to win. The media gently helped them lie.Journalists now declare in self-righteous tones that they care dearly about the facts and will never spread delusions. But Judy Woodruff threw a softball, asking Rice to explain the "serious charge" against Trump in her Post article. She never made the obvious point that Rice was the least qualified bureaucrat to lecture anyone about telling the truth on national security issues.Eli Lake's story on Rice wasn't evaluated for truth or falsehood. It was dismissed as a pro-Trump story designed to change the subject (or the target). ABC and NBC skipped any mention of it on their evening newscasts. CBS mentioned it in passing.CNN anchor Don Lemon spoke for many journalists as he hissed: "There is no evidence that backs up the president's original claim. And on this program tonight, we will not insult your intelligence by pretending otherwise, nor will we aid and abet the people who are trying to misinform you, the American people, by creating a diversion.""Aid and abet." The "objective" anchors at CNN treat the president as a criminal in their metaphors. The media don't care first about facts. They care first about liberal victory. Their hope now is to remove Trump from office. Keep that in mind when they speak.

PPL was founded in 1920 as a Pennsylvania utility. The utility began to expand its geographic reach beginning in the late 1990s, thanks to laws deregulating the industry. Today,…

Thor Industries (THO) topped fiscal second-quarter forecasts late Monday and the manufacturer of recreational vehicles plans to boost investments this fiscal year as it continues expanding production capacity.Estimates: EPS to surge 42% to $1.22 as revenue jumps 55% to $1.51 billion, helped by the acquisition of Jayco last year.Results: EPS of $1.23 on revenue of $1.59 billion. Towable RV sales leapt 55% to $1.08 billion, and motorized RV sales nearly doubled to $475 million. Backlogs: Towable RV backlog increased 87% to $615 million, and motorized RV backlog nearly doubled to $766.9 million.Outlook: Thor will invest $80 million in additional capital projects during the rest of the fiscal year, putting total capital investment for the full fiscal year at about $130 million vs. an earlier forecast for $95 million given in September. "Growing demand from new consumers broadening our market has continued, with younger families increasingly buying more affordably priced travel trailers and smaller motorhomes," said CEO Bob Martin in a statement. "These positive trends give us confidence that Thor and the industry will outpace volumes achieved in 2016, which was the best year of wholesale RV shipments since the 1970s.  We remain convinced that these trends will continue to drive industry growth in future periods, as we provide new consumers with positive experiences that prompt them to become lifelong RVers."  Martin added that expansion projects at its Keystone, Jayco and Heartland units should begin to ramp up over the remainder of fiscal 2017 and into fiscal 2018. Stock: Thor fell 3% late. Shares, which have a highest possible 99 Composite Rating, closed up 1.3% at 115.42 on the stock market today. Winnebago (WGO) finished down 0.6%. LCI Industries (LCII), the supplier to RV and manufactured home companies formerly known as Drew Industries, ended down 0.5%.In December, Winnebago topped fiscal Q1 forecasts, a month after completing its acquisition of towable-RV maker Grand Design as it seeks to counter Thor's towable brands like Airstream.Shares initially jumped but reversed sharply lower despite continued signs of strong demand in the market for towables, which are seen as lighter, less expensive, more fuel efficient and less costly to register and insure.

LGI Homes (LGIH) stock gapped up to a 5-month high Tuesday after the homebuilder reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and gave bullish guidance for 2017. Shares of rival builders such as Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH), Toll Bros. (TOL), Pulte Group (PHM) and D.R. Horton (DHI) rose modestly.LGI Homes earned $1.01 a share, up 35% vs. a year earlier, while revenue climbed 34% to $234.6 million. Wall Street had expected EPS of 94 cents on sales of $235.9 million. The builder sees 2017 EPS of $4-$4.50 a share, well above analyst targets of $3.74.Shares shot up 12.75% to 32.71 on the stock market today, rising to a 5-month high of 34.40 intraday and retaking their 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Investors should wait to see if LGI can continue building the right side of a proper base and break out of a proper buy point.Meanwhile, other homebuilder stocks continued to advance, as optimism about housing demand and stronger economic growth offset mortgage rates that are above pre-election levels.Lennar stock rose 1.5% to 50.71, hitting its best level since December 2015. Shares are now extended from a 47.69 buy point cleared last month. D.R. Horton climbed 1.5% to a six-month best. KB Home advanced 0.8% to 18.19 intraday, still in range from a 17.48 buy point. Luxury builder Toll climbed 1.1% to 35.47, now slightly more than 5% above a 33.58 buy point. Pulte Group rose 1.5% to 22.79, in range from a 22.08 entry.RELATED:Homebuilders Are Making Moves As Industry Leader Breaks OutToll Bros. Breaks Out On Earnings Gain

Stocks opened lower Tuesday, with company news and some late-season earnings reports stirring trading.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq composite lost 0.3%. The small-cap Russell 2000 was down 0.2%.Among stocks trading below 10, MeetMe (MEET) popped 14% after a strong fourth quarter earnings pre-announcement late Monday. Weatherford International (WFT) surged 18% after announcing a new CEO late Monday and receiving an analyst upgrade Tuesday morning.Exxon Mobil (XOM) fell 0.4%. Chief Executive Darren Woods announced on Monday $20 billion in spending plans, most of that aimed at expanding refineries and petrochemical facilities along the Gulf Coast.Dish Network (DISH) rolled out a 4.5% at the open. Standard & Poor's announced late Monday that Dish would join the S&P 500 Index next Monday, replacing Linear Technologies (LLTC). Linear is being acquired by Analog Devices (ADI). Dish is now extended from a pullback to the 50-day moving average and from a flat-base buy point of 59.67.Homebuilder LGI Homes (LGIH) popped 12% as fourth-quarter results squeaked past analyst estimates. Home closing increased 20% and the average sale price expanded 11% during the quarter. Management ratcheted up its full-year earnings guidance to well above consensus views, and trimmed only slightly its gross margin projections vs. fiscal 2016. LGI shares surged back above the 50-day and 200-day moving averages as they try to recover from a correction.Retailers were busy and all over the map in premarket action. Pier 1 Imports (PIR) posted a 9% gain at the open following quarterly results.Arts & crafts chain Michaels (MIK) popped 3% after fourth-quarter sales and earnings and first-quarter revenue guidance beat expectations. The stock has been trying to form a bottom in a steep decline that began in June.Casey's General Stores (CASY) dived 5% as RBC Capital downgraded the stock after a fiscal third-quarter miss reported late Monday. RBC cut its rating to sector perform, from outperform, and trimmed its price target to 123 from 136. Casey's shares fell to the lowest level in 11 months, sinking further below the 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) slipped 3%, nicked by fiscal 2018 earnings guidance that missed the consensus target, although fourth-quarter sales and earnings met or beat forecasts.China social networking site Momo (MOMO) skipped ahead 12.5%, after reporting an across-the-board fourth-quarter beat and hoisting first-quarter guidance to well above analyst targets. The IBD 50 stock is extended after topping a 23.96 cup-with-handle buy point in February.IBD 50 stock Thor Industries (THO) dropped nearly 6% at the open. The motorhome and RV trailer maker reported fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings just above estimates. Motorhome revenue rose 95%, towable RV segment income jumped 48% and management said it increased production during a normally slow first half of the fiscal year. The stock fell back near a 106.43 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.IBD 50 stock Sterling Bancorp (STL) dived 4% at the open. The Montebello, N.Y.-based bank announced Tuesday plans to buy Astoria Financial (AF) in a $2.2 billion cash/stock deal. Astoria shares soared 10%.Oil edged up 0.8%, with West Texas Intermediate sticking to its recent range between $53 and $54 a barrel. Gold traded down 0.3% to $1,222 an ounce. The dollar gained ground. The 10-year yield was unchanged at 2.50%.The trade balance widened in January to $48.5 billion, the Commerce Department reported, vs. a $44.3 billion deficit in December. The increase was in line with economist estimates.The Federal Reserve's January Consumer Credit report is due out at 3 p.m. ET.Europe's markets remained narrowly mixed in afternoon trade, with the FTSE 100 in London and Frankfurt's DAX each up less than 0.1%, while the CAC 40 lagged 0.4%.China's leading benchmarks in Hong Kong and Shanghai advanced 0.3%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 0.2% in a third straight decline.RELATED:Thor To Ramp Up Investments And Expansion After Q2 Tops3 Of These 4 Fast-Rising Groups Have Many Leaders Worth Watching

The Trump administration is less than a month old, and former Army Lt. Gen. Mike Flynn, the brand-new national security advisor, has resigned. This matches the picture the anti-Trump media want to paint right now: Chaos. Disarray. Amateur hour.They also expect the president to help them paint it. This is why they're going nuclear. But he chose to ignore them instead.Journalists came out of a joint news conference between Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau livid that the president had called on two "friendly" journalists instead of someone who would hammer him about Flynn. They bashed the two American questioners for asking the leaders about relations between the U.S. and Canada. But are the media elites really always hostile to "friendly" questioners?Former President Obama (and Democratic presidents before him) could always call on friendly journalists at these usually staid joint news conferences. Journalists didn't yell at one another for not being harsh enough. They had no interest in scalps in the first month.Over the last eight years, the press was never interested in making trouble for Obama. Instead, it projected the opposite. He was "scandal-free." If he had trouble, it didn't come from a rough news conference. It emerged from evil Republicans who were plotting.Exhibit A is ABC's Terry Moran. Eight years ago at this time, Moran interviewed the new liberal president for "Nightline." He looked at Obama in sorrow and said, "Mr. President, you got no honeymoon, not a single Republican vote in the House on your first major piece of legislation." He then speculated: "I wonder, in coming into the presidency, maybe you were too nice. If I'm a Republican senator or a Republican Congress, I think you're a very nice guy but I don't have enough reason to fear you."But on the day of the Trump-Trudeau news conference, Moran went on Twitter to hail former New Hampshire Republican Party Chairman Fergus Cullen for "ripping the sh*t out of Stephen Miller's (and POTUS) claims of massive voter fraud in NH." He then retweeted thirteen tweets in which Cullen mocked Trump's voter fraud claims with pop culture references from "The Simpsons" to "The Partridge Family.'Exhibit B is Brian Williams, whose 2009 prime-time Obama White House special featured a trip for cheeseburgers (What a regular guy, that Obama!) and good night handshakes and bows. He said: "Mr. President, that is your elevator. Thank you, sir. Have a good evening."But when it came to pounding Trump and Flynn, Williams displayed his typically shameless audacity, complaining that "no matter how robust the press corps covering the president, the president controls the flow and the topics in a de facto way by deciding who to call on and who not to call on."Obama controlled his flow by calling on Williams.Exhibit C is CBS News promoting White House correspondent Major Garrett's lament. He said, "The central personnel question hanging over the Trump White House was not asked."That's especially rich coming from the network of Obama's "60 Minutes" sympathizers. Steve Kroft offered Obama five softball interviews in 2008 in which he skipped every social issue, from gays to abortion to quotas. He also skipped health care and climate. And he skipped Rev. Jeremiah Wright and Bill Ayers. Kroft threw "hardballs" like, "Do you think the country is ready for a black president?" Once he became president, Kroft graduated to asking, "So have you gotten into a routine?"These exhibits could fill a floor of the Newseum. All you need to know is that journalists have an on-off switch for accountability. It was off for eight years. Now it's on, and they're lamely pretending it's always been on.

The New York Times was correct in 2011 when it proclaimed that "Saturday Night Live" has no equal "when it comes to stamping a politician in the public consciousness." Republican politicians like former Gov. Sarah Palin were described as incapable of escaping the "SNL" treatment, and voters actually thought Palin uttered Tina Fey's satirical line "I can see Russia from my house."And yet, the NBC show couldn't seem to locate a comedic angle on President Barack Obama, as the Times noted after his third year in office. He came into the White House as his impersonator Fred Armisen lamely spoke over a cool jazz beat: "I take my kids to school,/ I don't lose my temper,/ It's my only rule/ I keep it cool."Hilarious it was not. It reeked of adoration.In 2012, "SNL" writer Jim Downey was still declaring Obama mockery impossible. He said: "Obama doesn't give you much to grab onto. He's like a smooth rock face of perfect obsidian with no ledges or toeholds, and your job is to scale 200 feet of it.""SNL" boss Lorne Michaels routinely — and ridiculously — claims the show is nonpartisan. This came even after two cast members quite seriously sang the '60s ballad "To Sir, With Love" to a picture of Obama the night after Trump's inauguration. After finishing the song, they broke out a mug reading "World's Greatest President."Two weeks later, "SNL" lurched in the opposite direction, this time with a dark and very unfunny portrayal of Trump senior advisor Kellyanne Conway as the psychopathic Glenn Close character in "Fatal Attraction." Her love interest in the skit is CNN's Jake Tapper. The fake Conway writhed and moaned in a sexual way about forcing Tapper to put her on television. He surrenders after she holds a knife to his throat, but then she accidentally falls out the window to her death, only to peel herself off the sidewalk and pull herself together like a horror movie monster as she says grotesquely: "I only have three lives left. See you on the news!"Reaction wasn't positive. "Prediction: the White House will use that sexist skit to dismiss all criticisms of Conway and lying more broadly," tweeted liberal Daily Beast writer Olivia Nuzzi. She also said: "Casting Kellyanne Conway as Glenn Close was a miscalculation on SNL's part. Will be interpreted as unfair and mean to a wife and mother."Other liberals agreed. NBC's own Andrea Mitchell said it was "Not Right." The New York Times found that the skit was unfocused with a "queasy edge of sexism."On Monday morning, ABC brought on leftist Muslim comedian Dean Obeidallah to praise the skit as empowering for liberals. He said: "I think it was actually really well done, and I think in today's day and age, comedy is cathartic. We need to be laughing at the Trump administration. For those people who don't like the Trump administration, it's a release and makes you feel good. I think it's empowering."ABC reporter Jonathan Karl disagreed. "I don't think it was funny. It seemed to be incredibly mean-spirited. This is somebody who has young children," he said. "What makes SNL so funny is when they cut a little bit toward the truth. That was just not an accurate portrayal of Conway. I mean, she is somebody who actually is pushed to do more television by the president. ... She has many more requests to go on television than those that she actually accepts. "For months now, the media have thrown every kind of screwball at Conway, but she keeps hitting everything out of the park. They loathe her, and now they're trying to ruin her.Alec Baldwin and "SNL" have been poking fun at Trump mercilessly for months. Hard-hitting? Of course. Funny? You better believe it. Trump's supporters — and President Trump himself — should laugh. But what is being done to Kellyanne Conway is no laughing matter. "SNL" needs to cut it out.RELATED:Donald Trump News & TweetsWhy Are Trump's Approval Numbers Low? Ask The HatersIs This Trump's Watergate, Or Revenge Of The Swamp People?

XThe highflying chip gear sector continues to soar thanks to an upbeat earnings report from Lam Research (LRCX).Lam Research stock was in record high territory on Wednesday after the company delivered a beat-and-raise earnings report late Tuesday. Lam Research rose 6.9% to 136.17 on the stock market today, hitting a new all-time high.IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group jumped 3%, the second-best performing group on the stock market today. The group, which includes 34 stocks, is ranked No. 2 out of 197 groups.Major players in the sector that popped Wednesday include Applied Materials (AMAT), up 3.15% to 39.25, and KLA-Tencor (KLAC), which climbed 3.2% to 97.59. Others getting a lift included Rudolph Technologies (RTEC), MKS Instruments (MKSI) and Advanced Energy Industries (AEIS).The one contrarian was ASML Holding (ASML), which reported what initially seemed to be upbeat results. Early Wednesday, Netherlands-based ASML reported first-quarter earnings of $1.12 a share, up 115% year over year, on sales of $2.07 billion, up 36%. Analysts were expecting 99 cents and $1.93 billion.Shares climbed 2.3% to 133.71 in morning action on better-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings. But shares soon reversed and were down 2.9% at 126.89 at the close, below their 50-day line. The stock set a record high of 134.29 on March 28.While ASML's first-quarter results were strong, its second-quarter forecast disappointed investors. The company guided to sales in line with expectations, with gross profit margin below views.Also, ASML raised doubts over how many extreme ultraviolet lithography systems could be built and shipped next year, Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Mehdi Hosseini said. Wall Street was targeting 24 systems for next year and ASML said 20, he said.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks includes three chip gear companies: Lam, Advanced Energy Industries and Applied Materials.Fremont, Calif.-based Lam earned $2.80 a share excluding items, up 137% year over year, on sales of $2.15 billion, up 64%, in the quarter ended March 26. Analysts expected Lam to earn $2.55 a share on sales of $2.13 billion.For the current quarter, Lam expects to earn $3 a share minus items, up 67%, on sales of $2.3 billion, up 49%. Wall Street had been modeling for Lam to earn $2.65 a share on sales of $2.19 billion in the June quarter.Lam stock received price-target increases from CFRA Research, Needham, Pacific Crest Securities, RBC Capital Markets and UBS.RELATED:Lam Research Exits March Quarter Like A LionThese Two Leading Chip Stocks At Make Or Break Moment

Last week, we learned from Piper Jaffray that teens love Apple (AAPL) iPhones, Nike (NKE) and Disney (DIS) movies.This week, a Conde Nast-Goldman Sachs report reveals the fashion, retail and beauty brands that their slightly older millennial peers love. L Brands' (LB) Victoria's Secret, LVMH-owned Sephora and Nike make the top three in favorability rankings, said Bloomberg, which acquired the results.And unsurprisingly, what millennials like and what Wall Street likes doesn't always overlap. Despite the recent softness in handbag trends, all three major purse makers made the list.Rounding out the top 10 favorites list were Coach (COH), Kate Spade (KATE), Michael Kors (KORS), Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Lululemon (LULU), DSW (DSW) and Nordstrom (JWN).Still, it's perhaps worrying for brick-and-mortar-based retailers that their greatest online nemesis is also climbing the ranks.IBD'S TAKE: The Conde Nast-Goldman Sachs study is but another reflection of the ongoing existential crisis faced by retailers — but the situation has created potential shorting opportunities for investors.Amazon (AMZN) topped the list as men's favorite retailer across all categories, said Bloomberg, citing the report, which also bestowed Amazon with the title of "Most-Loved Brand" overall.The recent Piper Jaffray teen survey showed similar results: Amazon gained ground as the No. 1 preferred shopping website among teens, reaching 43% share, said analysts."(Amazon) Prime adoption has increased across all income brackets in each of the past six surveys," said Piper Jaffray analysts in last week's note.L Brands rose 1.5% on the stock market today. Nike fell 0.45%. Kate Spade lost 0.6%. Michael Kors dipped 0.1% while Coach fell 0.3%.Ulta Beauty fell 1.2% to 279.46, still above a 274.09 buy point but dipping below its 50-day moving average after undercutting that support level for the first time this year.Amazon slipped 0.5% to 899.20, just in range from an 860.96 four-weeks-tight entry. (The 5% chase zone ends at 904).RELATED:The Strongest Evidence Yet For An iPhone 'Supercycle'?Nike Is No Longer The Top New Apparel Brand For Teen Boys: Piper Jaffray SurveyWalt Disney Is In Buy Range, And You Can Thank Teens
