The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged Wednesday after its two-day policy meeting, as expected, and longer-term rate projections show an even slower pace of increases.Still, policymakers painted a mostly upbeat picture about the job market and overall growth and signaled that the Fed's key rate will rise before year-end.Markets have increasingly been pricing in a December hike -- currently 59% --  but have seen just a 33% chance of another hike before September 2017. Fed projection materials point to two hikes in 2017, consistent with recent comments that they would hold rates low for longer.The Fed said in its statement that policymakers decided that "the case for an increase in the federal funds rate has strengthened but decided, for the time being, to wait for further evidence of continued progress."However, three policymakers dissented from the decision, all favoring a hike now, leaving a 7-3 vote in favor of staying put.But the Fed's forecasts show policymakers expect three rate hikes through the end of 2017, down from five at their June meeting. The estimate for the fed funds rate in 2017 has slipped to 1.1% in 2017 from a 1.6% view in June, 2018's views dropped to 1.9% from 2.4%, and the longer-run forecast is now 2.9% vs. 3%.Investors seemed pleased with the Fed's intentions, sending stocks significantly higher and the Nasdaq to an all-time best. The 10-year Treasury yield fell slightly.The Fed assessment that "the labor market has continued to strengthen" seems to be a little too upbeat, given some surprisingly bleak details in the August jobs report, notably that the length of the workweek had shrunk to a five-year low. The latest data from Treasury also point to a weakening in federal income and employment taxes withheld from paychecks.The read on household spending — "growing strongly" — also seems to ignore the back-to-back declines in retail sales as auto sales went into reverse. The statement does note that business investment continued to be soft.Despite the Fed's positive read on economic data and a backdrop of core inflation approaching the 2% target, policymakers clearly think that they can be very patient in hiking rates over the next couple of years with little chance of an outburst of inflation.At her post-meeting press conference, Fed chief Janet Yellen characterized current policy as only "modestly accommodative."Earlier, the Bank of Japan vowed to keep the 10-year Japanese government bond yield near zero. The yen initially sold off hard against the dollar, but then reversed all of its losses and more as markets signaled doubts that the latest moves would be any more successful in reviving inflation than prior ones.Japan's plight is clearly in the thinking of Yellen and other Fed doves who stress that it will be easier to tamp down inflation should it surprise to the upside than it would be to shake off a bout of deflation."We're not seeing evidence that the economy is overheating," Yellen said. Meanwhile, more people are being drawn into the workforce than she had expected, giving the economy some extra running room, she said.Yellen noted that she sees the recent 180,000-per-month employment gain as unsustainably high.She also discussed commercial real estate, highlighted as an area of potential overheating by Eric Rosengren, president of the Boston Federal Reserve. "While valuations are high," Yellen said, she noted that lending standards have tightened and that debt growth was not raising red flags.So why didn't the Fed hike Wednesday? "Our decision does not reflect a lack of confidence in the economy," Yellen said.But she added that labor market slack is being taken up at a slower pace. And the Fed's "cautious" approach on rates reflects her belief that with rates near zero it would be easier to tighten quickly if necessary than to cut rates rapidly.Even though economists see a November rate hike as almost unthinkable given the presidential election just days later, Yellen stressed that the meeting would be a live one, meaning a rate move is possible.U.S. stocks opened higher on the BOJ moves as well as on strong earnings from Adobe Systems (ADBE) and FedEx (FDX), but had erased most of those gains heading into the Fed announcement at 2 p.m. ET.Among Fed-sensitive stocks, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and LGI Homes (LGIH) have found support near their 50-day lines recently.JPMorgan is still up after the Fed meeting, but has pared gains. LGI Homes is nearly up 2%, close to session highs.RELATED:JPMorgan, Goldman, Citi Sag As Rates To Stay Lower For LongerThe Fed's Real Dilemma Wednesday And How It May Disappoint MarketsNote To The Fed: The Job Market Just Took A Wrong TurnBank Of Japan Keeps -0.1% Rate, Sets Bond Yield Target

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) on Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings per share and sales that topped analyst estimates, but many stocks in the sector fell at the open on weaker housing-start data in August.Lennar said that earnings rose 5% to $1.01 a share, topping estimates for 89 cents. Revenue rose 14% to $2.8 billion, above forecasts for $2.68 billion.The Commerce Department on Tuesday said housing starts in August fell from July to an annualized rate of 1.142 million, worse than expected.Lennar's deliveries during the quarter rose 7%, while new orders rose 8%. The company said deliveries increased in all its homebuilding segments except in Houston, which suffered from "less demand in the higher-priced communities driven by volatility in the energy sector."Gross margins on home sales were 22.6%, slimmer than the 24.1% a year earlier in part due to steeper land costs. Deliveries and new orders were also weaker than the 12% and 10% gains seen, respectively, in the prior two quarters.At midday, Lennar closed 3.5% lower at 43.50 in the stock market today. KB Home (KBH), which missed third-quarter sales estimates but beat on earnings after the close, ended down 2.4% but rose 5% late. LGI Homes (LGIH)  fell 1.4%, while Pulte Group (PHM) lost 2.9%. Toll Bros. (TOL) slid 1.4%.The slump reverses the gains homebuilder stocks saw on Monday, when the National Association of Homebuilders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index showed that homebuilder sentiment in September was at an 11-year high."While the housing market's recovery has continued to progress on a slow, steady and sometimes, choppy path, we have continued to manage our sales and delivery targets in the 7% - 10% range, while focusing on bottom-line profitability and balance sheet strength," Lennar Chief Executive Stuart Miller said in a prepared statement.IBD'S TAKE: As the market digests mixed housing data, see which stocks in the sector could be gearing up for a breakout.KB Home earned 42 cents a share on revenue of $913.3 million. Net orders rose 16%, and deliveries grew 11%. Analysts expected earnings to jump 69% to 39 cents a share with revenue up 12% to $944.56 million.RELATED:  LGI Homes Raises Guidance As Home Prices Climb 6%LGI Homes Breaks Out; Rival Builders Near Buy Points

Stocks closed well off session lows but slightly higher Tuesday.The Nasdaq climbed 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 closed with tiny gains of less than 0.1%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. the same time Monday, according to preliminary figures.Biotech, energy and transportation stocks led the upside in today's stock market action, while telecom, oil and building-related plays lagged. In economic news, August housing starts and building permits disappointed. All eyes Wednesday will be on the Fed, when its interest rate decision is due out around 2 p.m. ET. A news conference follows at 2:30 p.m. ET.Amphastar Pharmaceuticals (AMPH) soared 12% to an all-time high in massive trade. Shares are 19% extended past a 17.90 cup-with-handle entry, nearing profit-taking range. The biotech, which develops injectable and inhalation drugs, will be added to the S&P SmallCap 600 index Wednesday after the close. Supernus Pharmaceuticals (SUPN), a maker of drugs to treat central nervous system disorders, pared its gain to 2% after rising as much as 5% intraday. The biotech is 6% extended from a 24.10 flat-base entry from where it broke out Thursday.IBD'S TAKE: Going with the top stocks in its industry group is always a sound strategy. Find out where your biotech ranks in its group now with IBD Stock Checkup.On the IBD 50, Acacia Communications (ACIA) reversed lower for a 4% loss. Shares of the fiber-optic products maker remain well extended past a 45.85 buy point of a short IPO base cleared in July.LGI Homes (LGIH) shed nearly 2% in light trade to test its 50-day line. The stock appears to be finding support there, but it also triggered a sell signal Sept. 9 when a sharp dive erased a double-digit gain from a 36.54 buy point. Homebuilders flagged Tuesday on weak housing starts data.IBD 50 stocks on the rise included Biogen (BIIB), up 1% amid strength in the biotech sector, as the stock builds a flat base with a 333.75 buy point. The biotech group has jumped to No. 11 among IBD's 197 industry groups, from No. 38 six weeks ago.Ireland-based drugmaker Shire (SHPG) added 1.5% in healthy volume as shares cleared a 203.47 flat-base entry. While the stock is still in buy range, be extra cautious with all purchases while the market uptrend is under pressure.Besides the Fed meeting, there's little else on the economic calendar. The Energy Information Administration's weekly oil inventory figures come out at 10:30 a.m. ET. General Mills (GIS), CarMax (KMX) and Red Hat (RHT) are some of the noteworthy companies reporting earnings.RELATED:Lennar Rises Above Q3 Views, But Housing Data Sinks SectorEpilepsy Drugs Fuel Huge Growth At Supernus; Pipeline Strong Too

No. 2 chip-gear-maker Applied Materials (AMAT) reported record earnings late Thursday and fiscal Q3 sales near Wall Street's expectations, as the company's guidance handily beat views, prompting shares to rocket in after-hours trading.Applied Materials stock was up 4.5% in after-hours trading, after the chip-gear maker released its earnings report and after closing up 1.4%, at 27.68, during the regular session in the stock market today, closing just below a 14-year high touched Monday. Shares are up 48% this year, amid IBD's 34-company Electronic-Semiconductor Equipment industry group's 15.5% rise.For its fiscal Q3 ended July 31, Applied Materials reported $2.82 billion in sales and 50 cents earnings per share minus items, up 13% and 52%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier quarter. EPS topped analysts' model for 48 cents. Sales neared the $2.84 billion forecast.Three months ago, Applied Materials' implied guidance was for $2.79 billion to $2.89 billion in sales and 46-50 cents EPS ex items.New orders jumped 26% to $3.66 billion. Its backlog of $4.95 billion rose 60% vs. the year-earlier period.Current-quarter guidance for sales to rise 15%-19% sequentially implies $3.24 billion to $3.36 billion, which would be up 39% vs. last year at the midpoint. Applied Materials' guidance crushed the consensus of 23 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $2.8 billion.Applied Materials also models 61-69 cents EPS ex items, up 124% and topping analysts' views for 48 cents.Applied Materials trails only ASML (ASML) in terms of market cap in IBD's 34-company Electronic-Semiconductor Equipment industry group.At one time, Lam Research's (LRCX) pending merger with KLA-Tencor (KLAC) appeared poised to overtake Applied Materials. Now, Applied Materials' $29.7 million value would still swallow a combined Lam-KLA by more than $4 million. ASML leads the group with a whopping $44.9 billion value.IBD'S TAKE: Lam's attempt to buy KLA is currently stalled on regulatory concerns with analysts saying earlier this month that Samsung, Hitachi and Tokyo Electron could put up an antitrust fight, pummeling the $10.6 billion merger.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) late Wednesday confirmed that it would ax thousands of jobs and reported Q4 earnings that topped views, though revenue declined 2% amid weakness in China.The computer networking leader said it will slash 5,500 positions, about 7% of its workforce, starting this quarter. Reports had anticipated as many as 14,000 job cuts.Cisco said it will target growth in security; the Internet of Things, or web-connected devices; and cloud computing. More acquisitions could be coming in growth areas, Cisco said.Under CEO Charles Robbins, who took over in July 2015, Cisco has targeted software, services and recurring revenue. On Cisco's earnings conference call with analysts, Robbins said the company will continue investing in its core business -- routing and switching gear -- while targeting growth areas."We are working diligently on bringing innovation to our core, we're focused on a tighter coupling of security into the core, bringing cloud-based management across the portfolio," he said. "It's not that we're ignoring one area in favor of the other, we want to make sure our investments are commensurate with the growth opportunity."Robbins said Cisco's job cuts are not related to its budding partnership with Sweden-based Ericsson (ERIC). There's been speculation Cisco could acquire Ericsson, though the gear maker has said that's not in the cards.Cisco said fiscal Q4 earnings per share minus items rose 7% from the year-earlier quarter to 63 cents. Revenue fell 2% to $12.6 billion. Analysts had projected EPS ex items of 60 cents, on revenue of $12.57 billion, for the quarter ended July 30.In the current quarter, Cisco forecast flat revenue of $12.5 billion, in line with views, and non-GAAP EPS of 59 cents, a penny below consensus estimates.Cisco stock was down 1% in after-hours trading, after its earnings release and confirmation of the layoff. Shares fell 1.3%, to 30.72, in Wednesday's regular session on reports it would slash 9,000 to 14,000 workers, raising questions over "whether forward business trends are weakening," one analyst said. Cisco laid off some 11,000 workers between 2011 and 2014.Cisco stock touched 31.25 on Aug. 9, its highest price since November 2007.IBD'S TAKE: Cisco's stock has climbed 13% in 2016, with most gains coming after upping its dividend by 24% in February. Some high-dividend-paying stocks, such as AT&T, have edged down on speculation the Federal Reserve might hike rates this year. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup. Large companies are shifting to outsourcing computer workloads to cloud computer services offered by Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google.

American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) beat quarterly estimates but saw comp sales cool sharply, while Children's Place (PLCE) lifted its outlook after a strong quarter.Overall retail sales were flat in July after three straight months of gains, the Commerce Department reported last week. Many retailers, restaurants and other consumer-related companies have reported sluggish demand.But some retailers are performing better than others. American Eagle and Children's Place shares are trading at multiyear and all-time highs, respectively, ahead of their earnings.Estimates: EPS to climb 23.5% to 21 cents. Sales seen up 2.9% to $820.18 million.Results: EPS jumped 35% to 23 cents while sales rose 3% to $823 million. But same-store sales only rose 3%, after rising 11% last year.American Eagle sees Q3 EPS of 40-41 cents vs. the 40 cents analysts are expecting.Last Quarter: EPS up 47% to 22 cents, as sales rose 7% to $749.4 million.Stock: American Eagle shares fell as low as 17.55 in morning trading but recovered to close down 3.3% at 18.33 on the stock market today. That's after hitting a three-year high of 19.55 on Monday. The stock, which had risen for the past eight weeks, is just below an 18.59 buy point cleared last week.Why It Matters: American Eagle, a leading teen and young adult retailer, is among a handful of apparel chains to break out in recent weeks amid a mixed consumer environment. American Eagle also may offer clues about how well the back-to-school shopping season has gone.Estimates: Analysts see a loss of 23 cents per share vs. a 33 cent per share loss in the year-earlier quarter. Sales are seen up 0.6% to $368.6 million.Results:  The retailer reported a loss of 1 cent per share and a 1.4% increase in sales  to $371.4 million. Same-store sales were up 2.4%.Children's Place raised its full year EPS outlook to $4.60-$4.70 from an earlier outlook of $4.17-$4.27. Analysts are expecting $4.26.Last Quarter: EPS up 59% to $1.32. Sales rose 4% to $419.4 million.Stock: Children's Place, a children's apparel retailer, climbed 1% to 86.69 after hitting a record 90 in early trading. On Tuesday, the stock finished the day at 85.86, up 2.7% ,closing above an 85.01 buy point in a consolidation, a bullish chart pattern. Volume was strong.Why It Matters: Like American Eagle, Children's Place offers hints about consumer spending, notably the back-to-school shopping period.IBD'S TAKE: Ross Stores and Lululemon Athletica are apparel retailers that have broken out. Is Children's Place next? Take a deep dive in this IBD Stock Analysis. Lower-ranked Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) topped quarterly estimates after the close, sending the stock up late.Urban Outfitters (URBN), another young adult apparel chain, soared 15% after better-than-expected Q2 earnings late Tuesday.Off-price apparel chain Ross Stores (ROST) reports Thursday. Peer TJX Cos. (TJX) gave cautious guidance Tuesday.Related:

Stocks ended slightly higher Wednesday after Federal Reserve policymakers were split on the need for an interest-rate hike. Cisco Systems (CSCO) dipped 1% after the close, while NetApp (TAP) jumped 5% after reporting earnings.The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1% and the Nasdaq ended up a fraction. Volume in the stock market today was higher across the board, according to preliminary data.Stocks erased mild gains in the afternoon, after minutes from the Fed's July 27 meeting showed policymakers had greater confidence in the economic outlook, but remained reluctant to raise interest rates.Computer networking giant Cisco Systems was down about 1% after the close despite reporting higher-than-expected profit and sales for the fiscal fourth quarter that ended in July. The stock dipped 1% during the regular session, ending just below a 52-week high. It was reported that Cisco plans to lay off 14,000 workers or about 20% of its global workforce.Agilent Technologies (A), a maker of scientific measuring instruments, fell 5% after the close following its quarterly results.NetApp (NTAP) jumped more than 5% in post-session trading after the maker of network storage and data management hardware posted better-than-expected fiscal Q1 profit and sales.The stock is working on a long and deep cup-type base.Chinese social networking stock YY (YY) was up 3% after the close after its Q2 results. The stock has retaken its 10-week moving average but is hitting resistance at its 40-week line as it tries to recover from a long slide.Retail stocks were hardest hit during the regular session, following disappointing earnings reports.Lowe's (LOW) dropped more than 5% after the home improvement retailer reported that profit for the fiscal second quarter that ended in July rose 9% to $1.31 a share, below Wall Street expectations.Sales edged up 5% to $18.3 billion, also below views.But L Brands (LB) popped 3% in post-session trading after the parent of Bath & Body Works and Victoria's Secret posted better-than-expected Q2 profit and sales. The company also raised its full-year profit outlook.Ross Stores (ROST), Applied Materials (AMAT), Toro (TTC) and Foot Locker (FL) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic data due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Aug. 13, the Philadelphia Fed's index of mid-Atlantic manufacturing for August and The Conference Board's Index of Leading Economic Indicators for July.

In the stock market, it's totally smart to always have an exit strategy for every stock you buy. When a stock does not behave, the exit strategy is very simple. Cut your losses short. While a 7%-8% loss is the largest you should allow, cutting your losers even more quickly is sound strategy, especially during choppy market conditions or in…

The mass shooting in Orlando really infuriated liberals all over again about the lack of gun control -- including liberal journalists and comedians. NBC "Nightly News" anchor Lester Holt blandly promoted how "late-night hosts have once again found themselves straddling the lines between comedians and consolers."But they weren't consolers. They were agitators for the liberal agenda.On "The Daily Show," host Trevor Noah sympathized with Obama saying, "He's hosted 12 state dinners, but he's had to give 16 mass-shooting addresses."And none of those apparently ever reflected badly on Obama's leadership on terrorism? Noah lectured for gun control: "America needs to ask itself the question: Do you want to be a country that takes reasonable measures to protect its citizens, or should we tell the president to prepare speech number 17?"On NBC's "Late Night," hosted by Seth Meyers, the only issue was guns: "This was an attack on LGBT people fueled by bigotry and hatred. And the shooter was apparently inspired by ISIS, " he acknowledged.He continued: "But we're gonna talk about guns. Because whether the shooter was a homophobe, mentally ill, a terrorist inspired by ISIS or all three, what allowed him to kill so many people on Sunday was his gun. And that means we're likely about to enter yet another contentious national debate about gun control."Later, Meyers lamented saying, "When given a chance, Congress consistently chooses nothing as a course of action."On TBS, Conan O'Brien used almost the exact same language about banning "assault rifles" as Hillary Clinton does on the campaign trail. He began by noting, "I've always, always made a policy to stick to my job and keep my opinions to myself."Don't buy that. O'Brien likes comparing Donald Trump to Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini.He continued: "I simply do not understand why anybody in this country is allowed to purchase and own a semiautomatic assault rifle. It makes no sense to me. These are weapons of war, and they have no place in civilian life."O'Brien can take his 10-pound pompadour to Cuba, make a communist dictatorship look colorful and lovable, and keep his opinions on their repression to himself. But conservatives and Republicans? They're like Hitler, and they like murderous assault rifles.Also on TBS, Samantha Bee echoed O'Brien, sounding like a Democrat, but with added rage: "Sam Bee wants to take your guns away! Yes, the ones that mow down a room full of people in seconds? Yes, I do want to take those guns away. These high-capacity penis substitutes are a s***** choice for hunting and home protection, but perfect for portable mayhem."But Bee added a layer of contempt for anyone who offered prayers of support to the victims and their families: "The biggest, most helpful thing you can do to ensure this never happens again is sit quietly in a room with your eyes closed, talking to nobody."She concluded her rant with a mean-spirited prayer of her own: "I'm just going to pray. Are you there, God? It's me, Sam. Please, bless the victims and their friends and families in their time of unspeakable pain. Give us the courage to say no more, and while you're at it, please send the NRA a plague of boils. Amen."If Lester Holt thinks Samantha Bee is a "consoler," he's clearly in denial about her weekly rage-fest.These comedians are all angry that their editorials never seem to make a dent, in part because they cannot acknowledge that their "solutions" (like background checks) never seem to be the answer to these unfolding mass-shooting horrors.

Yet the market's choppiness has made it clear that stock investors still have a bad case of the jitters. You'd have to look at other asset classes…

Off-price earnings are scheduled for this week, with TJX (TJX) reporting early Tuesday, and off-price peer Ross Stores (ROST) slated to disclose results after the close on Thursday.A number of department-store retailers surprised the Street last week with earnings and revenue beats, so what can investors expect from the two major off-price stocks?The parent of T.J. Maxx, Marshall's and HomeGoods, TJX is expected to earn 81 cents in per-share profit, a 1% gain from the prior year. Revenue is seen growing nearly 7% to $7.85 billion.IBD's Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories industry group, which includes TJX, Ross Stores, Gap, Foot Locker (FL) and others, has been on a four-session win streak, collectively rising 4% since last Tuesday.While the off-price sector has generally been outperforming the broader bricks-and-mortar retail space, the Retail-Department Stores group is up 19% over the same time frame, on the backs of well-received results from Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Nordstrom (JWN) last week. Nordstrom did well on its off-price Nordstrom Rack stores.TJX shares briefly popped out of buy territory earlier Monday but are now back in the zone, dipping 0.1% to 82.77 by the close. The stock had broken out of a flat base with 79.30 entry point in mid-July.IBD'S TAKE: Several companies set to report this week are near buy points. For more on those stocks, read IBD's Investing Action Plan for Tuesday.Meanwhile: Ross Stores, which also operates DD's Discounts, is expected to grow per-share earnings by 6% to 67 cents on a 5% sales rise to $3.1 billion.Shares hit buy range in late July after building a 4-months-long flat base with 59.78 entry. But the stock is slightly overextended now past the range's 62.77 ceiling, closing at 63.22 on Monday.Among other retailers reporting this week: Gap (GPS), Urban Outfitters (URBN), American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB).

Samsung, Hitachi and Tokyo Electron will likely mount a regulatory attack on Lam Research's (LRCX) $10.6 billion bid to acquire KLA-Tencor (KLAC), but that's only if U.S. regulators don't kill the deal that would unite two of the largest makers of chip-manufacturing equipment, analysts said Thursday.KLA stock fell 2.8% to 67.51 in the the stock market today after toppling 10% on Wednesday when Lam said that regulatory hurdles in South Korea, China and/or Japan might extend the merger's close beyond the Oct. 20 deadline.Lam stock fell 4.5% Wednesday, and closed down 0.25% to 88.89. Shares are 6% extended from an 83.93 entry point achieved June 2. KLA stock, on the other hand, is down more than 8%, in a sell zone, from a 73.69 buy point hit June 20.The Lam-KLA merger has been riddled with antitrust concerns since its announcement last October. This is the third time the deal has been delayed, Nomura analyst Romit Shah wrote in a research report Thursday.Shah downgraded Lam stock to neutral from buy and cut his price target to 85 from 95.IBD'S TAKE: Lam stock has a high IBD Composite Rating of 90, meaning it performs in the top 10% of all stocks. KLA stock trails with a CR of 84.In May, the U.S. Department of Justice sent a "second request" asking for more information into Lam's plan to buy KLA, likely over antitrust issues.Combined, Lam-KLA would have a $25 billion market cap, trailing leaders ASML (ASML) and Applied Materials (AMAT) with $46.9 billion and $29 billion, respectively. The duo would have 21% market share and be No. 1 or No. 2 in three out of four major manufacturing process steps."This announcement reinforces a growing trend of skepticism from the DOJ that merger remedies will be sufficient to prevent higher prices," Shah wrote. "Recent examples include Halliburton (HAL)-Baker Hughes (BHI), Sysco Foods (SYY)-US Foods (USFD) and Albertsons-Safeway."Semiconductors Advisers President Robert Maire noted KLA could ask Lam for more money or terminate the deal. Unlike Applied Materials abandoning its bid on Tokyo Electron in the face of antitrust concerns, Lam can't easily walk away from KLA.And foreign regulators are just as apt as U.S. regulators to question the antitrust angle, Maire wrote in a research note."We are sure that Samsung is pushing Korean regulators for two pounds of flesh," he wrote. "And Japanese regulators are probably well aware of the 'fox guarding the hen house' problem from both Tokyo Electron and Hitachi."

ETFs investing in precious metal mining companies surged Friday as soft consumer and retail data caused major stock indexes to retreat and supported higher gold prices.Global X Gold Explorers (GLDX) jumped 2.9% in morning trade on the stock market today. The ETF sits just below its 52-week high of 45.90.VanEck Vectors Gold Miners (GDX), the largest exchange traded fund holding gold stocks, popped as much as 1.8% to 31.79, retaking the 52-week high of 31.79 set in Thursday's session.Spot gold's price was up 1.1% at $1,352.51 an ounce at around 10:30 a.m. ET.Retail data pushed the dollar lower, bolstering the price of gold. An official report showed retail sales were flat in July. Consumer confidence for August also came in below expectations. The data suggest consumer momentum -- a recent pocket of relative strength -- could be waning and impact the Fed's next interest rate move.Higher rates raise the opportunity cost of holding gold, a nonyielding haven asset.IBD'S TAKE: OPEC countries are continuing to produce at peak levels and lack of unanimity on a production freeze among cartel members could keep prices volatile in the near term.MLP funds also made a sturdy advance Friday as major oil producers opened the door to possible action on stabilizing crude prices. WTI crude futures traded up 1% at 43.92 a barrel at 10:47 a.m. ET.Alerian MLP (AMLP) swung 0.7% higher to 12.69. Energy MLPs own and operate liquid and gas pipelines along with storage sites and processing units that bring energy products to market.Investors bid up defensive fund sectors such as utilities, consumer staples, real estate and longer-term government bonds intraday.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes are performing today, with IBD RS Ratings.The RS (Relative Price Strength) Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.1%, RS 57PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.1%, RS 64SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.1%, RS 53IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), 0%, RS 64IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), 0%, RS 67IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), 0%, RS 32Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -0.3%, RS 73SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +1.1%, RS 67United States Oil (USO), +0.9%, RS 14IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.4%, RS 32PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.3%, RS 27IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -0.7%, RS 1

LGI Homes (LGIH) shares jumped Tuesday after the home builder reported second-quarter results above analyst estimates Tuesday and raised guidance as the number of homes the company closed on and their average selling price rose.Earnings rose 45.5% to 96 cents per share, beating analyst views by 9 cents. Revenue jumped 40.2% to $222.7 million, above analysts' views for $219.5 million. Home closing during Q2 climbed 32.2% to 1,128 vs. the year-earlier quarter. The average home price rose 6% to $197,450.IBD'S TAKE: LGI tops the building group but is still out of buy range, while KB Home is just in buy range. Find more top building stocks here.LGI raised its full-year EPS guidance to $3.20-$3.70, largely above consensus for $3.27, from a prior outlook of $3.00-$3.50.LGI shares ended trading up 6.7% to 34.50 on the stock market today. Lennar (LEN) shares were up 0.5% to 46.83. Toll Bros. (TOL) ticked up 4 cents to 27.89, and KB Home (KBH) added 0.6% to 15.73.

For more than a year, the cable news networks have feasted on Donald Trump, covering him live, day after day, for hours and hours. Republican contenders couldn't hope to get a fraction of his TV time. Now that Trump has secured the Republican nomination, is it possible that the networks will "suddenly" lose interest in every Trump speech?On successive days, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump gave speeches at the Veterans of Foreign Wars national convention. This is usually a greater test for Democratic candidates, since they have a liberal base full of "peacemakers" and Pentagon-haters.On July 25, Clinton spoke, followed by Trump the following day. But no one can figure out how CNN would define one as a big, breaking-news event and the other as news equivalent of a bathroom break. CNN aired the entire Clinton speech -- 19 minutes and 20 seconds -- live and uninterrupted in the 11 a.m. hour (Eastern time). The next day, CNN failed to air a single second of Trump's VFW speech live.After Clinton spoke, CNN anchor John Berman summarized her theme: "It started out sober and subtle. But by the end, it was flat-out trolling Donald Trump, though not by name," with statements like "I don't understand who people who trash-talk America."The next day, morning anchor Carol Costello said that Trump was in North Carolina, saying, "We'll take you there, next." But all viewers saw was CNN reporter Sara Murray, their reporter on the Trump beat, briefly guessing about what Trump was saying inside.Tough criticism of Clinton on Benghazi and the Obama record on veterans' health? Not news. What were they doing instead during that hour?Before Trump spoke, CNN chose to offer 2 minutes and 23 seconds of live coverage to a Bernie Sanders speech to Democratic delegates from Wisconsin at the Democratic National Convention. Just about 20 minutes later, CNN also aired another minute and 19 seconds of the socialist's speech to Democratic delegates from California. His campaign was over. He was trying to get his followers into the Clinton tent. That noise was still airing on CNN as Trump's speech began.Instead of offering live coverage of Trump's VFW speech, Costello gave more time to Trump's opponents while he was talking. She promoted how Democrats are exploiting Trump's coarse mockery of disabled New York Times reporter Serge Kovalesky to raise money. She brought on former Rep. Tony Coelho and threw a softball. "Tell me about the fundraising off of that Donald Trump moment in the disabled community?" she said.Coelho gushed: "With this situation, Donald Trump has insulted us. He has given us an opportunity to be aggressively for Hillary ... this gives us a moment to go for it in fundraising, Facebook, everything that we're doing."How partisan did CNN look? It's this bad: MSNBC, the "Lean Forward" network, gave Trump's speech almost 5 minutes of live coverage -- compared to 14 minutes and 41 seconds of live coverage of Clinton's speech. Fox News carried all 24 minutes and 37 seconds of Trump's speech. But Fox also awarded more time to Clinton's speech than MSNBC did -- 16 minutes and 43 seconds.The Republicans who thought Trump was some sort of specially weaponized candidate against the Democrats because the TV networks could not possibly skip his live events may find themselves very disappointed. CNN's indefensible "news" judgment on the VFW speeches suggests that this highly anticipated publicity spigot is going to be turned off now that Trump's opponent is Hillary Clinton, and not other Republicans.
