IBD's Screen of the Day, Top Fundamentals, is all about the long-term: Companies with track records of superior earnings and sales growth.

But this article will focus on five "fundamentals" stocks that report earnings over the next week: LinkedIn (LNKD), Facebook (FB), Paycom Software (PAYC), Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Molina Healthcare (MOH).

 LinkedIn reported after the close on Thursday. Analysts had expected earnings to fall 12% to 46 cents a share as it expands it sales force and boosts its research and development spending. Revenue was projected to grow 33% to $755.6 million. Instead, LinkedIn EPS jumped to 78 cents ex items. Revenue rose 37% to $780 million, including $41 million from lynda.com.
The professional social network, which has an IBD Composite Rating of 89 out of 99, shot up 9% in late trading after closing up 1.8% in the stock market today.
 Molina Healthcare also reported much better than expected earnings late Thursday. Shares rose 1% late after closing down 1.2%, slightly below the 200-day line.
Molina, a provider of managed health care services for low-income families, has an 89 Composite Rating and a three-year EPS growth rate of 113%.
 Paycom Software is expected to see earnings rise 40% to 7 cents when it reports after the close next Tuesday, Nov. 3. Revenue is seen increasing 41% to $51.5 million.
The provider of cloud-based employment-management software earns a near-best Composite Rating of 98. Paycom has been a big winner in 2015, fell 0.2% Thursday, just above its 50-day line.

 Facebook issues its results after the close next Wednesday. The social networking giant's earnings are projected to rise 21% to an adjusted 51 cents a share. Revenue is seen climbing 37% to $4.37 billion.
The company has been public for only a little over three years, and it has a three-year earnings growth rate of 70%.
Facebook recently broke out of a base and is trading at all-time highs, rising 0.7% Thursday. The stock has a 99 Composite Rating.
 Regeneron Pharmaceuticals reports next Wednesday before the open. It's projected to see earnings climb 27% while revenue increases 45%.

The biotech's three-year EPS growth rate is 104%. Like Facebook, Regeneron also has a 99 Composite Rating. Shares, down nearly 2% to 560.02. It recently cleared a double-bottom-base buy point at 557.97.

Another month, another good jobs report that fuels the increasing expectation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month for the first time in a decade. In November, 211,000 nonfarm jobs were added in the U.S., leaving the unemployment rate unchanged at 5%, the Labor Department said. Revisions also added 35,000 more jobs in September and October…

Yahoo (YHOO) got a price target hike early Wednesday after the Internet company shelved plans to spin off its stake in Alibaba Group (BABA), while Intel (INTC) was upgraded and ConocoPhillips' (COP) price target was lowered.

FBR Capital raised Yahoo's price target to 44 from 39 and maintained its outperform rating on the stock. On Tuesday, reports surfaced that Yahoo will scrap the planned spinoff of its 15% stake in China e-commerce leader Alibaba, citing tax concerns.

Instead, Yahoo will create a new publicly listed company to hold all of its assets excluding its Alibaba stake, Reuters reported Wednesday morning. The new company will house Yahoo's Internet business as well as its 35% stake in Yahoo Japan.
Yahoo shares closed down 1.3% on thestock market today. Alibaba lost 1.1%.
Intel's stock price rose 0.2% after it was upgraded to buy at Nomura.

Oil and gas giant ConocoPhillips had its price target cut to 65 from 82 by Argus Research, which still has a buy rating on the stock. ConocoPhillips is expected to post its first annual loss in more than a decade in 2015 amid a depressed market for oil and gas. Even so, its stock price rose 0.3%.

AutoZone's (AZO) price target was raised to 789 from 726 by RBC Capital Markets, which has a sector perform rating on the No. 1 U.S. auto parts retailer. AutoZone shares shot up nearly 6% on Tuesday after it beat fiscal Q1 earnings expectations and posted a 3.5% gain in domestic same-store sales, though shares declined 1.5% Wednesday.

Defense supplier L-3 Communications (LLL) gave up 2.9% after its price target was cut to 129 from 131 at RBC Capital Markets. On Tuesday, CACI (CACI) agreed to buy L-3's government IT business for $550 million.

Shares of Krispy Kreme (KKD) rose 4.4% even though the doughnut chain's price target was cut to 24 from 27 by Roth Capital. On Tuesday, Krispy Kreme logged a 6% third-quarter earnings gain and a 5% revenue increase.
Electronics manufacturer Jabil Circuit (JBL) sank 5.6% to 24.24 after it was downgraded to hold from buy at Stifel . Jabil shares set a new high of 26 on Dec. 4.

Macquarie Securities downgraded American Movil, which faces intensified competition in Mexico from AT&T (T) as growth slows in Brazil and at its U.S. subsidiary, TracFone.

Kevin Smithen, an analyst at Macquarie, said in a research note that America Movil's (AMX) plans to expand in Europe seem at a dead end. TracFone, meanwhile, added only 13,000 subscribers in the September quarter. Revenue was flat from the year-earlier period.

T-Mobile US (TMUS) and AT&T have stepped up marketing in the prepaid market, where customers buy calling time and data as needed. AT&T and T-Mobile have aimed at upgrading their prepaid subscribers to postpaid plans, with monthly installment payments for phones. Postpaid users are generally more lucrative than prepaid users.
TracFone had 25.7 million prepaid subscribers as of Sept. 30.

"In the U.S., America Movil does not appear willing to sell its TracFone asset despite clear signs of prepaid-to-postpaid subscriber migration," wrote Smithen, who downgraded America Movil stock to neutral.

TracFone has partnered with Wal-Mart (WMT) for U.S. distribution. Wal-Mart has been selling a 3G mobile phone, manufactured by LG, for under $10 that uses TracFone's services. The LG phone's specifications are similar to Apple's (AAPL) first iPhone, said one report .

TracFone leases network capacity from U.S. wireless firms, but AT&T has taken on former partner American Movil in Mexico. AT&T acquired Mexico's No. 3 wireless firm, Iusacell, for $1.7 billion last year and bought Nextel Mexico out of bankruptcy for $1.87 billion. AT&T also is spending $3 billion to upgrade its wireless network.
Carlos Slim Helu, one of the world's richest men, controls America Movil.

"It was clear to us from Mr. Slim's comments at the recent analyst day that America Movil's expansion into Europe was initially part of a grander plan involving AT&T and either Vodafone (VOD) or Telecom Italia," Smithen wrote. "With those deals not happening, we feel that America Movil could be shut out of larger-scale European M&A in the coming years."
America Movil stock was down 1% in early trading in the stock market today, within pennies of a more than six-year low touched on Aug. 24, the day the market overall crashed.

Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor's (KLAC) impending marriage left little "attractive or sizable" in the dating ring for Applied Materials (AMAT), one analyst suggested late Thursday after the No. 1 chip gear-maker reported mixed Q4 earnings.
But, investor relief led Applied Materials stock to jump Friday. In midday trading on the stock market today, shares were up 5% near 17.50.

For its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 25, Applied Materials reported $2.37 billion in sales and 29 cents earnings per share ex items. The consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters saw slightly higher revenue, $2.4 billion, while EPS met their expectations.

Applied Materials guided Q1 sales down 2%-9% sequentially, implying revenue of $2.24 billion at the midpoint of guidance vs. the consensus forecast for $2.27 billion and year-ago revenue of $2.36 billion.
The company also sees 23-27 cents EPS ex items. A year earlier, EPS came in at 27 cents. For the current quarter, Wall Street has been expecting 25 cents.
'Bad But Not Horrible'

Fiscal Q4 was "bad but not horrible," Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire wrote in a research report. (Semiconductor Advisors is a financial and strategic advisory firm to semiconductor and clean-tech industries. In his former capacity as a Morgan Stanley analyst, Maire helped raise $1 billion for Applied Materials and $800 million for KLA-Tencor.)
Applied Materials stock closed down 1.6% Thursday, but rose in after-hours trading.
"The Street was clearly braced for the storm that didn't happen as there was a bit of a relief rally after hours when it turned out that the report, while bad, was not a disaster," Maire wrote.

Late Thursday, Applied Materials reversed year-earlier guidance for a 5%-10% jump in fiscal 2015 sales, saying 2015 would be flat vs. 2014. Fiscal 2016 will be flat with heavier sales in the second half.
Maire wondered where Applied Materials would see growth.

"Applied Materials keeps talking about share gains and organic growth, but we don't see it as being enough to a move a needle as heavy as Applied Materials," he wrote. "We really need some 'shot in the arm' good, old-fashioned inorganic growth to get things going again."
Dickerson Dodges M&A Speculation
It's unlikely M&A action will stoke that growth, he wrote. CEO Gary Dickerson dodged M&A speculation during the Thursday conference call with analysts.
"We're very selective in the opportunities that we look for," he said. The company looks for financial return, strategic alignment and leadership. "The hurdle for us is very high," he added.
Maire theorized Applied Materials must be looking "harder than ever given the Lam-KLA announcement. The problem is that there's just not a lot left that's all that attractive or sizable."
Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan suggested Applied Materials consider a break-up. A hypothetical break-up in 2011 resulted in a higher value than then-stock price, he wrote in a report.
Focus On 3D Nand

Meanwhile, Q1 orders are shaping up well, he wrote. In 2016, 80% of spending will be focused on 3D Nand (flash memory), Dickerson told analysts Thursday. That compares with a 90% estimate at Lam Research, Credit Suisse analyst Farhan Ahmad noted in a separate report.
DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) spending, on the other hand, will be "down significantly," Dickerson said. DRAM bit demand is expected to be 25%-30%.
Applied Materials also guided current-quarter operational expenses up to $550 million vs. $544 million in fiscal Q4. But, a decline in calendar 2016 opex could add 3 cents to EPS, Ahmad wrote.
Continuing aggressive share buybacks could add 21 cents to fiscal 2016 EPS, he added. Over the course of two quarters, Applied Materials bought back $1.3 billion in shares (6% of its market cap).
Sundararajan rates Applied Materials stock a hold and issued a price target of 18. Ahmad boosted his price target on Applied Materials stock to 22.50 from 22 and rates it an outperform.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) stock gapped down Friday to a six-week low after the company gave lower-than-expected guidance late Thursday, with investors not appeased as yet with CEO Chuck Robbins' message that better days are ahead.The company's earnings and sales for its fiscal Q1, ended Oct. 24, beat Wall Street expectations, but its Q2 guidance missed."We're doing all the right things to drive our growth," CEO Chuck Robbins said on the company's earnings conference call. And he said those things would be more obvious in the "coming months."Just maybe not this month or next. Cisco guided the current-quarter earnings at 53 to 55 cents per share minus items, on revenue rising 0% to 2%. Analysts had modeled EPS up 6%, at 56 cents, and sales up 5%, to $12.55 billion.On the other hand, more than $1 billion in annual sales should accrue starting in 2018 from Cisco's "strategic partnership" with Ericsson (ERIC), Robbins had assured when he and Ericsson CEO Hans Vestberg announced the partnership Monday.FBR analyst Daniel Ives pointed out in a research note Friday that Cisco's Q1 security segment revenue had risen 7% despite touch comparisons with the year-earlier figure. He called that a "bright spot.""The company's impressive turnaround on this segment after years of pain and on the shoulders of its SourceFire acquisition (in 2013) now appears to be hitting its stride, which we loudly applaud," Ives said."We continue to point to massive strength in firewall spending and next-generation cybersecurity initiatives (unified threat management, endpoint, email, database security) heading into 2016, while 'emergency security spending' has ticked down, which clearly impacts FireEye (FEYE) more than any other vendor. Cisco security share gains have subsided as the company has finally figured out the right formula/better execution and now the focus is on identifying the winners in the land grab opportunity for this $30 billion cyberpie over the next three years."Ives said FireEye and possibly Fortinet (FTNT) could be Cisco acquisition targets in 2016 "for Robbins as he looks to significantly expand Cisco's security footprint in this fertile market for years to come."Similarly, Andrew Chanin, CEO of PureFunds, which offers the PureFunds ISE Cyber Security ETF (HACK) with Cisco as a top-10 holding, sees promise in Cisco's security products."Investments in areas like cybersecurity for the firm have the potential to provide some more growth as opposed to its other, more mature business lines," Chanin told IBD Friday. "It's a combination of them not just relying on their mature revenue-generating business units but expanding into those with more growth potential."FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi maintained his outperform rating on Cisco stock but lowered his price target to 32 from 35, "driven largely by uncertainty from macro (primarily outside the U.S.) and currency.""Although data center revenue of $850 million basically met consensus, its growth (23% year over year) continues to be strong as Cisco continues to take share in the server market," Syrafi wrote in a research note.Cisco stock was down 6% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 26.Among Cisco's healthiest networking rivals, Juniper Networks (JNPR) stock was down 3% Friday afternoon. Ericsson stock was down 2%, near 9, and is off 9% since its Monday gain following the partnership disclosure with Cisco.

Strong earnings growth is a key driver of a stock's performance. While some firms are on pace for robust bottom-line growth this year, a few are expected to do even better next year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see Facebook's  (FB) earnings rising 23% to $2.17 a share this year. Profit for the social network giant is projected at…

Universal Display (OLED), a developer of organic light-emitting diode screens for TVs and smartphones, has seen its stock rise on enthusiasm for OLED TVs and the possibility that Apple (AAPL) could use the technology in future iPhones.
But the market has gotten ahead of itself, Canaccord Genuity analyst Jed Dorsheimer said in a research report Wednesday.

"We believe near-term distractions and story-stock momentum have priced in market success well through 2017," Dorsheimer said. He reiterated his hold rating on the stock, but raised his price target to 52 from 41. Universal Display shares were down 1.7% to below 55 in afternoon trading on the stock market today. The stock hit a more than four-year high of 57.93 on Monday.
Investor expectations for Universal Display have gotten "frothy," Dorsheimer said.

OLED technology is maturing and seeing increased production yields, but OLED displays are still much more expensive than liquid crystal displays, Dorsheimer said. OLED TV price points continue to fall and are now two to three times LCD TV prices, he said. LG and Samsung are ramping up production of OLED televisions, which show deeper blacks and richer colors than LCD TVs. OLED TVs also consume less power than LCD sets.
Dorsheimer said his base case scenario assumes 2017 shipments of 2.3 million OLED TVs and 375 million OLED smartphones.
"Universal Display's success hinges on OLED TV adoption, but we are becoming incrementally positive on the probability of OLED TV success (even in the near term)," he said.

Shares of Universal Display and OLED display maker LG Display (LPL) jumped on reports last month that Apple is considering using OLED displays in its iPhones starting in 2018.Universal Display (OLED), a developer of organic light-emitting diode screens for TVs and smartphones, has seen its stock rise on enthusiasm for OLED TVs and the possibility that Apple (AAPL) could use the technology in future iPhones. Applied Materials (AMAT) stock reversed a down-day Thursday on Wall Street after reporting fiscal Q4 sales that topped analyst projections.
In early after-hours trading, Applied Materials stock was up 3.5%. Shares closed down 1.5% in regular-session trading ahead of the No. 1 chip gear-maker's scheduled quarterly earnings report.
For its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 25, Applied Materials reported 29 cents earnings per share ex items on $2.37 billion in sales, both measures up 7% vs. the year-earlier quarter.

Sales topped the consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which saw $2.4 billion. Applied Materials' 29-cent EPS met the consensus and was the company's second-highest earning quarter behind Q3.
Three months ago, Applied Materials guided to a 7%-to-flat decline in sales vs. Q3 sales of $2.5 billion. The company also saw 27-31 cents EPS minus items.
Fiscal 2015 sales of $9.7 billion, up 6% year over year, and $1.19 EPS ex items, up 11% vs. the year-ago quarter, also narrowly beat the consensus — which saw $9.6 billion and $1.18.
For the current quarter, Applied Materials sees revenue falling 2-9% sequentially and 23-27 cents EPS. In the year-ago quarter, the company reported 23 cents EPS on $2.2 billion in sales.

Applied Materials is in IBD's 36-member Electronic-Semiconductor Equipment industry group. The company has a middling Composite Rating of 49 out of a best-possible 99. Lam Research (LRCX) tops the group with a CR of 91.

Lam might also swipe Applied Materials' No. 1 slot in the chip gear-making sector with the recently announced acquisition of KLA-Tencor (KLAC) (CR of 85), Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire theorized in a recent research report.
Or, Applied Materials could make a play for KLA by topping Lam's $10.6 billion bid.
"We have to admit that our first reaction to the announcement of the Applied Materials/Tokyo Electron deal was shock that Applied Materials didn't make a play for KLA first," Maire wrote.
The Tokyo Electron deal floundered for nearly two years before it died in the water.

Lam and KLA announced their merger as Western Digital (WDC) confirmed rumors by making a $19 billion play for SanDisk (SNDK), beating out potential interest from Micron Technology (MU) and Seagate Technology (STX) amid mass chip sector consolidation.
KLA's process control operations are superior to Applied Materials' operations, Maire wrote.

"It's more synergistic and, perhaps more importantly, blocks Lam or ASML Holding (ASML) from getting their hands on this crown jewel in the industry," he wrote. "Bottom line, KLA is worth jumping through hoops for."

Fresh off the thrill of announcing a megapartnership with Ericsson designed to boost sales right away while the pair jointly develop cloud and 5G "networks of the future," as they called it, Cisco kicked off its fiscal 2016 with disappointing guidance.
The networking gear leader, however, posted earnings per share and sales that beat expectations for its fiscal Q1, which ended Oct. 24.

The San Jose, Calif.-based company late Thursday said that it expects Q2 earnings per share minus items of 53 to 55 cents on revenue that would be flat to up 2% vs. the year-earlier quarter. Analysts had estimated Q2 EPS ex items at 56 cents, up 6%, on sales of $12.55 billion, up 5%.
"Yes, the guidance was lower," Cisco (CSCO) CEO Chuck Robbins acknowledged with analysts on the company's earnings conference call. "But nothing has changed about how I feel about the business. ...
"We're doing all the right things to drive our growth," which he said would be more obvious in the "coming months."

Cisco Systems stock was down 5% in after-hours trading, after the company released its earnings. Shares rose a small fraction in Thursday's regular session, to 27.83, down nearly 6% from 29.49 touched on Oct. 26, the stock's highest price since June 1.
Rival Juniper Networks (JNPR), which saw its shares touch a four-year high of 32.39 last week, rose a fraction in Thursday's regular session, to 29.65, and was up a fraction after hours.

"We guided to solid growth in Q2," Robbins said in the company's earnings release. "Our guidance reflects lower-than-expected order growth in Q1, driven largely by the uncertainty of the macro environment and currency impacts."
For Q1, Cisco said that earnings minus items rose 9.3% to 59 cents per share on revenue of $12.7 billion, up 3.6%.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS of 56 cents on sales of $12.65 billion. In August, Cisco guided Q1 EPS ex items at 55-57 cents and revenue at $12.495 billion to $12.74 billion.

Cisco said that sales of its core switches rose 5% but core router sales fell 8%. Switching gear is Cisco's legacy and largest revenue segment, about 30% of sales in fiscal 2015; routers were next, at 16%.
Legacy Players Challenged
Analysts say that Cisco is challenged to deliver the growth of smaller rivals that are speeding the migration of consumers and enterprises to cloud networks and mobile platforms.

"As evidenced by the company's lighter-than-Street outlook, Cisco as well as many of its mature tech stalwart peers are facing a challenging environment, which is exacerbated by a choppy IT spending environment," FBR analyst Daniel Ives told IBD. "We are seeing a bipolar spending environment in technology, and traditional IT vendors that play in the networking, storage and data center (space) are getting disproportionately hurt.
"Headwinds are massive for these players, and every quarter is like a Groundhog Day. Growth is like grass growing."

Acknowledging the challenge on Monday, Cisco and Ericsson (ERIC) CEOs announced a strategic partnership that each said was its company's most significant — "by far," Ericsson CEO Hans Vestberg emphasized. They said that the partnership is expected to generate more than $1 billion in additional annual sales for each firm by 2018, with accretion starting in 2016.

With fewer details but similar superlatives, on Aug. 31 Cisco and Apple (AAPL) announced a unique partnership to build mobile networks — a "fast lane," they said — aimed at bringing Apple's smartphones and other mobile devices deeper into business and enterprise markets. Mostly a consumer phenomenon, Apple has a long runway for iPhone, iPad and PC growth in business and enterprise markets, which Cisco can help it penetrate.

At the Morgan Stanley TMT conference Wednesday, Cisco Executive Chairman John Chambers said: "Partnership will be as important over the next two decades as acquisitions were over the past two decades for us," Reuters reported. "If we do it right, our peers won't be able to keep up."
Nonetheless, Cisco closed Q1 on a flurry of acquisitions and positioned others to close in during Q2.
In Q1, Cisco completed the acquisitions of OpenDNS, MaintenanceNet and Pawaa Software, complementing its security, services, software and cloud offerings.
In Q2, Cisco expects to close on the purchases of Portcullis, ParStream, Lancope and 1 Mainstream in the security, data analytics and video areas.

Thursday's slight stock gain was Cisco's first this week, despite Monday's Ericsson disclosure.Fresh off the thrill of announcing a megapartnership with Ericsson designed to boost sales right away while the pair jointly develop cloud and 5G "networks of the future," as they called it, Cisco kicked off its fiscal 2016 with disappointing guidance.The networking gear leader, however, posted earnings per share and sales that beat expectations for its fiscal Q1, which ended Oct. 24.The San Jose, Calif.-based company late Thursday said that it expects Q2 earnings per share minus items of 53 to 55 cents on revenue that would be flat to up 2% vs. the year-earlier quarter. Analysts had estimated Q2 EPS ex items at 56 cents, up 6%, on sales of $12.55 billion, up 5%."Yes, the guidance was lower," Cisco (CSCO) CEO Chuck Robbins acknowledged with analysts on the company's earnings conference call. "But nothing has changed about how I feel about the business. ..."We're doing all the right things to drive our growth," which he said would be more obvious in the "coming months."Cisco Systems stock was down 5% in after-hours trading, after the company released its earnings. Shares rose a small fraction in Thursday's regular session, to 27.83, down nearly 6% from 29.49 touched on Oct. 26, the stock's highest price since June 1.Rival Juniper Networks (JNPR), which saw its shares touch a four-year high of 32.39 last week, rose a fraction in Thursday's regular session, to 29.65, and was up a fraction after hours."We guided to solid growth in Q2," Robbins said in the company's earnings release. "Our guidance reflects lower-than-expected order growth in Q1, driven largely by the uncertainty of the macro environment and currency impacts."For Q1, Cisco said that earnings minus items rose 9.3% to 59 cents per share on revenue of $12.7 billion, up 3.6%.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS of 56 cents on sales of $12.65 billion. In August, Cisco guided Q1 EPS ex items at 55-57 cents and revenue at $12.495 billion to $12.74 billion.Cisco said that sales of its core switches rose 5% but core router sales fell 8%. Switching gear is Cisco's legacy and largest revenue segment, about 30% of sales in fiscal 2015; routers were next, at 16%.Legacy Players ChallengedAnalysts say that Cisco is challenged to deliver the growth of smaller rivals that are speeding the migration of consumers and enterprises to cloud networks and mobile platforms."As evidenced by the company's lighter-than-Street outlook, Cisco as well as many of its mature tech stalwart peers are facing a challenging environment, which is exacerbated by a choppy IT spending environment," FBR analyst Daniel Ives told IBD. "We are seeing a bipolar spending environment in technology, and traditional IT vendors that play in the networking, storage and data center (space) are getting disproportionately hurt."Headwinds are massive for these players, and every quarter is like a Groundhog Day. Growth is like grass growing."Acknowledging the challenge on Monday, Cisco and Ericsson (ERIC) CEOs announced a strategic partnership that each said was its company's most significant — "by far," Ericsson CEO Hans Vestberg emphasized. They said that the partnership is expected to generate more than $1 billion in additional annual sales for each firm by 2018, with accretion starting in 2016.With fewer details but similar superlatives, on Aug. 31 Cisco and Apple (AAPL) announced a unique partnership to build mobile networks — a "fast lane," they said — aimed at bringing Apple's smartphones and other mobile devices deeper into business and enterprise markets. Mostly a consumer phenomenon, Apple has a long runway for iPhone, iPad and PC growth in business and enterprise markets, which Cisco can help it penetrate.At the Morgan Stanley TMT conference Wednesday, Cisco Executive Chairman John Chambers said: "Partnership will be as important over the next two decades as acquisitions were over the past two decades for us," Reuters reported. "If we do it right, our peers won't be able to keep up."Nonetheless, Cisco closed Q1 on a flurry of acquisitions and positioned others to close in during Q2.In Q1, Cisco completed the acquisitions of OpenDNS, MaintenanceNet and Pawaa Software, complementing its security, services, software and cloud offerings.In Q2, Cisco expects to close on the purchases of Portcullis, ParStream, Lancope and 1 Mainstream in the security, data analytics and video areas.Thursday's slight stock gain was Cisco's first this week, despite Monday's Ericsson disclosure.

The major averages fell again Tuesday, though they closed well off their session lows. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.9% and the S&P 500 fell 0.6%. The Nasdaq, boosted by biotech and software stocks, edged 0.1% lower. Volume was mixed, running higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.

Losers topped winners by more than 2-to-1 on the NYSE and by a 3-to-2 margin on the Nasdaq. Biggest decliners in the stock market today included transportation, metal ore miners and building-related stocks. Auto parts retailers, medicals and software makers outperformed.Southwest Airlines (LUV) gapped down and sank 9% in fast trade. Before the open, the discount carrier said operating revenue per available seat mile will be flat to 1% lower in Q4 vs. a year ago. The stock fell as much as 6% below a 47.27 buy point from a cup base cleared in early November.Toll Bros. (TOL) slumped 7%, slicing its 50-day moving average in heavy trade after the homebuilder's fiscal Q4 earnings missed views. Revenue, however, came in above forecasts. The stock has been consolidating since mid-August.IBD 50 builders D.R. Horton (DHI) fell 1%, while LGI Homes (LGIH) reversed upward for a 1% gain after recovering from a near 5% early loss. LGI is still well below its 50-day line, which it gave up Monday during an 11% plunge.Citrix Systems (CTXS) led the IBD 50 on the upside, rising 3% to retake its 50-day line and a 76.38 buy point. Shares of the software maker triggered a sell signal last week after falling 8% below the entry.Desktop software maker Adobe Systems (ADBE) reversed upward for a 2% gain. It's now extended from an 86.09 cup-with-handle buy point. Analysts expect Adobe to earn 60 cents a share, up 67% from a year ago, when it reports Thursday after the close.Smith & Wesson (SWHC) surged 5% in massive trade, padding its 8% gain from Monday. The stock marked a new high and is far extended from a 19.07 cup-with-handle buy point. The firearms maker was down after hours despite reporting fiscal Q2 earnings above views.Economic data slated for Wednesday include the Mortgage Bankers Association's mortgage applications and the Energy Information Administration's weekly petroleum status report, both for the week of Dec. 4.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo and on Facebook.

The S&P 500 gave up 0.7% after being down as much as 1.2% at Monday's low. Energy stocks were battered as crude oil tumbled nearly 6%, to $37.65 a…

Most traders have likely run into rough patches in their investment journeys. Many have likely experienced spells where practically every trade that they put on went on to lose money. Or they end up with a series of investments that produced mediocre results overall.

There's no substitute for years of live trading under different market conditions. Yet in order to improve, investors sometimes need to go back and revisit their investment education roots. One way to get better results is to reread the books where you learned about the CAN SLIM investment methodology in the first place.

A future column on the topic of improving investment results will focus on attending one of the live investing workshops, which are great. IBD home study courses featuring the content of such workshops and IBD University, found online on investors.com, give a serious investor the opportunity to repeat materials any time, any place.

Yet good investment books will always pose an excellent long-term method for learning, and they are cost-effective. Books allow you to learn and review principles on your own time and go about it on your own pace.

Most investors should go back and revisit "How to Make Money in Stocks" (HTMMIS), which is the bible of CAN SLIM investing. Even if you've read the book once or twice already or are doing pretty well in the market, spend some extra time and go over it, cover to cover. You might just find some gems of Bill O'Neil's decades of market knowledge that you previously missed.

If you've had poor results lately, ask yourself what exactly you're having trouble with. Is it market timing? The condition of the general market can have a big impact on whether you'll have a successful trade or not. Are you buying too late into a new confirmed uptrend? If so, go back to Chapter 9, "M = Market Direction: How You Can Determine It."

Stock selection is key to great results. Are you buying the No. 1 or No. 2 stock in a highly rated industry group? These firms crank out innovative products and services that go on to dominate their respective industries. If you are not targeting such companies, read Chapter 7, "L = Leader or Laggard. Which Is Your Stock?"

A huge part of how you do in stocks involves selling. Are you taking gains once they amount to 20% to 25% when you have them? Nailing a few 20% to 25% winners in your portfolio can make for a good year.

And if you were lucky enough to catch some stocks that shoot up 50%, 75% or 100%, did you get out before they imploded after showing signs of climax action? If you're having trouble with this, revisit Chapter 11, "When to Sell and Take Your Worthwhile Profits."
Identifying sound bases is also key. There are many charts going back more than 100 years for investors to study from.
Yes, there are many pieces of the investment puzzle that investors have to put together to get the picture right.

For investors that don't have the time to go through HTMMIS from cover to cover, then pick up a copy of "The Successful Investor." This book, penned by O'Neil in 2004 following the 2000-02 tech bear market, goes over many key topics in CAN SLIM investing. Think of the book as a lighter version of HTMMIS.Most traders have likely run into rough patches in their investment journeys. You might think Spark would spark some interest among investors, but for the moment you can see a sparkle in Steven Milunovich's eye. Spark is Cisco's (CSCO) new collaborative product, now available in the cloud, to enhance its videoconferencing, messaging and phone services.
Collaboration amounts to about 11% of Cisco sales and "has been one of the bright spots," growing faster than other Cisco segments, UBS analyst Milunovich wrote in an upbeat research note Wednesday.

But in a down day for the market overall, Cisco stock was down 1.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 26.50, about where shares have lingered for three weeks, 11% off their 52-week high of March 2.
Spark is expected to be sold for up to $25 monthly per user as SaaS, or software-as-a-service.

Milunovich says Cisco's collaboration business and overall "sales acceleration should be helped" by Spark. He sees the collaboration business growing 9% in fiscal 2016 vs. 7% in '15, following two years of 6% declines.
But the service won't be rolled out entirely until Cisco's fiscal third quarter ending in April.

Maybe a Spark is what Cisco needs. Analysts have criticized Cisco, the legacy switching and router king, for not growing fast enough, at 4% in fiscal '15 to $49.2 billion. Cisco has partnered with Apple (AAPL) and most strategically with Ericsson (ERIC), and has purchased a bevy of cloud companies in recent months to speed up its growth.
Cisco unveiled Spark's cloud availability Tuesday.

"Voice, video conferencing and Web conferencing have historically tended to operate independently of each other," Milunovich said. "Cisco's Spark was built ground up to integrate these silos and it is delivered through the cloud, which has allowed the company to ship 40 new features in the last year.

"The cloud delivery mechanism also enables mobility and seamless hand-offs between telepresence units and phones. While many Spark features are available without hardware upgrades, we believe existing SX10 telepresence units may need to be upgraded to support Spark calling. Spark also has APIs (application programming interfaces) that make it easier for users to integrate third-party services (e.g: Dropbox, Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Apps, etc.)."
Cisco described Spark as "highly secure collaboration that is delightful to use. Today, most of us use unconnected tools for team messaging, virtual meetings and phone calls.

"Called Cisco Spark, our new offer mixes messaging, meeting and calling in such a simple way that it is hard to tell where one ends and the next begins. With Cisco Spark, all three are parts of a complete user experience."
UBS maintained a buy rating on Cisco stock, with a 33 price target.

"Cisco's valuation perhaps underestimates its opportunities," said Milunovich.You might think Spark would spark some interest among investors, but for the moment you can see a sparkle in Steven Milunovich's eye. Stocks were mostly lower going into the noon hour Wednesday. The Nasdaq fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 was down 0.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average inched fractionally higher in the stock market today. Volume was running lower on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchange compared to the same time Tuesday.

Gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC) rose as much as 4% early, but then gave up its gain by midday. It posted sharp advances Monday and Tuesday in the wake of the San Bernardino terrorist attack and a renewed debate over gun control laws. The company raised guidance in the face of rising gun sales.
Rival Sturm Ruger (RGR) was down more than 1% in volume running more than double its 50-day average. The stock has also risen sharply in recent days.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 13 were higher and 37 were lower. The best performer was Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL), holding company for an Argentine bank. The stock was up 4%. It had fallen below a 26.23 cup base buy point but found support at its 50-day moving average. On Nov. 29, Argentina elected Mauricio Macri its new president. He is viewed as more market friendly than the outgoing administration.

The worst performer in the index was LGI Homes (LGIH), down nearly 5%. The stock has been a star among the homebuilders since breaking out of a base Aug. 5, but it has stumbled in recent days, plunging decisively below its 50-day moving average.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) fell more than 8% after reporting disappointing Q3 results, as earnings per share fell 17% to 35 cents, even as sales picked up 14% to $479.7 million. There's $14 billion up for grabs in fiscal 2016 cybersecurity spending by the sector's biggest customer — the federal government — and Palo Alto Networks (PANW), FireEye (FEYE), Fortinet (FTNT) and CyberArk Software (CYBR) are vying for their respective chunks of cash.
But some are doing better than others.

FireEye stock plunged to a record low 21.75 on Nov. 5 after reporting Q3 sales that missed Wall Street views and guiding below consensus expectations. The resulting 23% sell-off drew CyberArk stock into the fray.

CyberArk, which beat-and-raised on its Q3, dropped 4% after a stellar quarterly report that included 10 new federal customers within the executive and legislative branches. Since then, both companies have suffered continued losses on Wall Street.
Despite their opposite-ends-of-the-spectrum reports, both companies acknowledge that federal spending on cybersecurity is ramping up as headline-making breaches drive awareness across all spheres.

In the latest big case, the Justice Department announced charges Nov. 10 against three men for what it termed "massive computer hacking crimes against U.S. financial institutions, brokerage firms and financial news publishers." The financial sector hacks involved stealing the personal information of over 100 million customers, and a maze of other cyberattacks are said to amount to one of the largest thefts of financial-related data in history.
Attacks Skyrocket
Between fiscal years 2006 and 2014, cyberattacks on federal agencies increased nearly 12 times over, from 5,503 to 67,168, according to a recent report by the U.S. Government Accountability Office.
Federal spending isn't keeping up.

Between 2014 and 2016, federal cybersecurity spending grew 40% — compared with the 1,100% increase in attacks over the past eight years. The GAO report didn't provide figures for attacks occurring in individual years.
Inarguably, though, the biggest attacks occurred on the back end of that eight-year period.
In May, hackers accessed about 334,000 taxpayer accounts.
A month later, an Office of Personnel Management (OPM) breach resulted in the release of 21.5 million employee records.
More recently, in October, the U.S. Postal Service was targeted. The scope of that hack is still under investigation.

In November, U.S. officials suggested that Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps was responsible for a recent surge in cyberattacks against American government employees, the Wall Street Journal reported.

The Obama Administration has been hyperfocused on cybersecurity protections, FBR analyst Daniel Ives told IBD. Earlier this fall, China and the U.S. appeared poised to sign a peace treaty centered on cybersecurity.
It's a small step, Ives said.

"But ultimately, it's still a game of high-stakes poker, and there's still a high threat level in terms of cyberespionage," he said. "I think that's why the U.S. government can't just sit there and hope it's going to go away, because these threats are as pervasive and sophisticated as we'll ever see."
'The Writing On The Wall'
So where does that leave cybersecurity companies?
Potentially with a huge sales runway, Ives says.
"There's a limited pool of companies that can handle this type of work," he said.

Ives sees FireEye, Palo Alto Networks, Imperva (IMPV), Fortinet, Symantec (SYMC) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) taking huge chunks of the federal cybersecurity spending market. Ives estimates the market opportunity at $20 billion over the next three years.
The "rip-and-replace" age of legacy cybersecurity systems is still in its infancy, Ives said, and it's going to drive deal sizes to unforeseen numbers.
Perhaps the perfect cautionary tale, however, is FireEye — which recently plunged on disappointing sales and a week Q4 outlook.

FireEye was dealing with a tough comparison quarter, CFO Michael Berry told analysts during the conference call. In Q3 2014, FireEye signed a five-year, eight-figure deal with a federal agency. No such deal emerged in Q3 2015. The company's average contract length slipped to 30 months from 34 months in the year-earlier quarter.
FireEye was specifically hurt by depressed European sales on the strengthened U.S. dollar.
On a nine-month basis, federal sales are great, CEO David DeWalt told analysts on the call.
"The federal sales model has been a shining star for the company," he said. "(But) when you look at Q3, maybe (we're) not quite where we had hoped to be."
FireEye representatives didn't return a request from IBD for comment by press time.
During Q3, Palo Alto Networks swiped FireEye's head of federal sales, Nick Urick. FireEye hired David Ramirez of L-3 National Security Solutions to take Urick's post.

"You can see the writing on the wall here, where Palo Alto Networks just hired away the head of FireEye's federal sales team," Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski told IBD. "They're building up their sales representatives, and we're starting to see a lot of security vendors trying to move into that space."
Rogue Credentials
The recent onslaught of attacks buoyed other companies.

For its Q3, Israel-based CyberArk reported sales and earnings that trounced Wall Street's expectations, assisted by 10 new contracts within the federal executive and legislative branches, CEO Udi Mokady told analysts during the conference call.
The federal government's Sept. 30 fiscal year-end typically means bolstered fall-quarter sales for companies like CyberArk.

But it was the OPM breach and the government 30-day Cybersecurity Sprint initiative that really increased awareness, Mokady said. U.S. Chief Information Officer Tony Scott launched the Sprint in June, forcing federal agencies to examine and better their cybersecurity practices.
Privileged-account policies, CyberArk's specialty, was No. 3 on the list of issues that federal agencies had to address.

A privileged account has administrative access to a computer system. On average, every organization — the federal government included — has three to four times the number of privileged accounts as employees, CyberArk Chief Marketing Officer John Worrall told IBD.
To put that number in perspective, "One bank told us they stopped counting at 1 million," he said.
The motivation to protect those accounts is clear. But attackers can be nimbler than the enterprises that they target.

"One of the biggest challenges organizations face is the attackers can often be more agile than the organizations," he said. "(CyberArk software) adds the ability to detect anomalous behavior ... that helps level the playing field."

From a federal government perspective, CyberArk must protect rogues from getting in and insiders from going rogue, Worrall said. He cited Edward Snowden's release of thousands of National Security Agency documents as an example of the latter.
To the former point, he said: "Once the outsider comes in, he's going to steal the credentials of an insider, and at that point, honestly, you won't know the difference."
Risk Aversion Runs Deep
Cybersecurity firms are hesitant to break out specific numbers.

Neither CyberArk nor Palo Alto Networks would delve deeper into the percentages of total revenue that federal sales comprise. Last month, Fortinet said that it received 12% of its Q3 sales from the government sector — but that figure includes international revenue as well.

During Symantec's Q3 earnings call this month, CEO Thomas Seifert would say only that Symantec's U.S. federal business "did very well." Last month, Qualys CEO Philippe Courtot told analysts that a tiny 1% of the company's sales in Q3 derived from federal contracts.
"So, as you can see, it's probably negligible," he said.
All taken, there's still a lot of room for growth, Palo Alto Networks' Vice President of Government Affairs and Policy Ryan Gillis told IBD.

The federal government lags the enterprise and private sectors in terms of next-generation technology adoption, he said. Procurement processes are slower, and certification processes often snag quick adoption.

Palo Alto Networks allows potential customers to trial its software, Gillis said. Between 80% and 90% of trial runners evolve into customers. But risk aversion within the government runs strong, and federal players generally spurn Palo Alto's offer.
"It's not an environment conducive to upgrading to the newest and greatest," he said. "It stems from understandable places but disadvantages the network in some cases."

That being said, the federal government realizes its precarious position as an international target, and some early adopters within the government have made mass headway into cybersecurity initiatives, Gillis said.

"The government certainly is a recipient of a range of attacks from run of the mill to very sophisticated stuff," he said. "You certainly get some demanding customers in the government that recognize the nature of the threats."

The scope of that hack is still under investigation.In November, U.S. officials suggested that Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps was responsible for a recent surge in cyberattacks against American government employees, the Wall Street Journal reported.The Obama Administration has been hyperfocused on cybersecurity protections, FBR analyst Daniel Ives told IBD. Earlier this fall, China and the U.S. appeared poised to sign a peace treaty centered on cybersecurity.It's a small step, Ives said."But ultimately, it's still a game of high-stakes poker, and there's still a high threat level in terms of cyberespionage," he said. "I think that's why the U.S. government can't just sit there and hope it's going to go away, because these threats are as pervasive and sophisticated as we'll ever see."'The Writing On The Wall'So where does that leave cybersecurity companies?Potentially with a huge sales runway, Ives says."There's a limited pool of companies that can handle this type of work," he said.Ives sees FireEye, Palo Alto Networks, Imperva (IMPV), Fortinet, Symantec (SYMC) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) taking huge chunks of the federal cybersecurity spending market. Ives estimates the market opportunity at $20 billion over the next three years.The "rip-and-replace" age of legacy cybersecurity systems is still in its infancy, Ives said, and it's going to drive deal sizes to unforeseen numbers.Perhaps the perfect cautionary tale, however, is FireEye — which recently plunged on disappointing sales and a week Q4 outlook.FireEye was dealing with a tough comparison quarter, CFO Michael Berry told analysts during the conference call. In Q3 2014, FireEye signed a five-year, eight-figure deal with a federal agency. No such deal emerged in Q3 2015. The company's average contract length slipped to 30 months from 34 months in the year-earlier quarter.FireEye was specifically hurt by depressed European sales on the strengthened U.S. dollar.On a nine-month basis, federal sales are great, CEO David DeWalt told analysts on the call."The federal sales model has been a shining star for the company," he said. "(But) when you look at Q3, maybe (we're) not quite where we had hoped to be."FireEye representatives didn't return a request from IBD for comment by press time.During Q3, Palo Alto Networks swiped FireEye's head of federal sales, Nick Urick. FireEye hired David Ramirez of L-3 National Security Solutions to take Urick's post."You can see the writing on the wall here, where Palo Alto Networks just hired away the head of FireEye's federal sales team," Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski told IBD. "They're building up their sales representatives, and we're starting to see a lot of security vendors trying to move into that space."Rogue CredentialsThe recent onslaught of attacks buoyed other companies.For its Q3, Israel-based CyberArk reported sales and earnings that trounced Wall Street's expectations, assisted by 10 new contracts within the federal executive and legislative branches, CEO Udi Mokady told analysts during the conference call.The federal government's Sept. 30 fiscal year-end typically means bolstered fall-quarter sales for companies like CyberArk.But it was the OPM breach and the government 30-day Cybersecurity Sprint initiative that really increased awareness, Mokady said. U.S. Chief Information Officer Tony Scott launched the Sprint in June, forcing federal agencies to examine and better their cybersecurity practices.Privileged-account policies, CyberArk's specialty, was No. 3 on the list of issues that federal agencies had to address.A privileged account has administrative access to a computer system. On average, every organization — the federal government included — has three to four times the number of privileged accounts as employees, CyberArk Chief Marketing Officer John Worrall told IBD.To put that number in perspective, "One bank told us they stopped counting at 1 million," he said.The motivation to protect those accounts is clear. But attackers can be nimbler than the enterprises that they target."One of the biggest challenges organizations face is the attackers can often be more agile than the organizations," he said. "(CyberArk software) adds the ability to detect anomalous behavior ... that helps level the playing field."From a federal government perspective, CyberArk must protect rogues from getting in and insiders from going rogue, Worrall said. He cited Edward Snowden's release of thousands of National Security Agency documents as an example of the latter.To the former point, he said: "Once the outsider comes in, he's going to steal the credentials of an insider, and at that point, honestly, you won't know the difference."Risk Aversion Runs DeepCybersecurity firms are hesitant to break out specific numbers.Neither CyberArk nor Palo Alto Networks would delve deeper into the percentages of total revenue that federal sales comprise. Last month, Fortinet said that it received 12% of its Q3 sales from the government sector — but that figure includes international revenue as well.During Symantec's Q3 earnings call this month, CEO Thomas Seifert would say only that Symantec's U.S. federal business "did very well." Last month, Qualys CEO Philippe Courtot told analysts that a tiny 1% of the company's sales in Q3 derived from federal contracts."So, as you can see, it's probably negligible," he said.All taken, there's still a lot of room for growth, Palo Alto Networks' Vice President of Government Affairs and Policy Ryan Gillis told IBD.The federal government lags the enterprise and private sectors in terms of next-generation technology adoption, he said. Procurement processes are slower, and certification processes often snag quick adoption.Palo Alto Networks allows potential customers to trial its software, Gillis said. Between 80% and 90% of trial runners evolve into customers. But risk aversion within the government runs strong, and federal players generally spurn Palo Alto's offer."It's not an environment conducive to upgrading to the newest and greatest," he said. "It stems from understandable places but disadvantages the network in some cases."That being said, the federal government realizes its precarious position as an international target, and some early adopters within the government have made mass headway into cybersecurity initiatives, Gillis said."The government certainly is a recipient of a range of attacks from run of the mill to very sophisticated stuff," he said. "You certainly get some demanding customers in the government that recognize the nature of the threats."Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Plunging energy prices sent the stock market into a tailspin in afternoon trading Thursday.The Nasdaq was down 0.4%, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average bore the brunt of the damage, off 1% in the stock market today.Volume was tracking higher than the same time Wednesday on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.Oil prices turned tail and were trading nearly 3% lower, well below $42 a barrel. OPEC said that crude oil stockpiles stood at 210 million barrels in the developed world, above the five-year average.St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said that the central bank should raise interest rates because emergency policies are no longer necessary with the labor market and inflation near the Fed's goals.Among Dow 30 stocks, 28 were lower, led by Caterpillar (CAT), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM), all down nearly 3%.Among IBD 50 stocks, eight were higher and 42 were lower. The worst performer was LGI Homes (LGIH), down 4%, but it remained above its 50-day moving average.The best performer was NetEase (NTES), which broke out of a cup base with a 154.98 buy point. Volume was massive, but the stock was trading in the lower half of its daily range and having trouble holding the buy point. It was up 3%.Among industry groups, energy, machinery and miners were among the worst performers on the day.Department stores were the top-performing groups. Kohl's (KSS) rose 5% after a cheery earnings report. But a disappointing Macy's (M) report on Wednesday sent the whole group deeper into a correction.

Stocks were off their lows of the day in early afternoon trading Friday as leading financial stocks struggled to hold above buy points.The Nasdaq fell l.8% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 0.6% each. Volume was running higher than the same time Thursday on both exchanges in the stock market today.Financial stocks, especially regional banks, that broke out of bases within the past week were having trouble staying above buy points. Signature Bank (SBNY) dropped below a 154.50 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. It was down 1%.Nashville, Tenn.-based Pinnacle Financial (PNFP) likewise slipped below a 55.58 buy point from a cup-with-handle base, also down less than 1%.Bank of America (BAC) slipped 1% and Citigroup (C) was down 0.4%, recovering much of an earlier loss.Despite financial sector weakness, investors are still prepared for a interest rate increase at the Fed's Dec. 16 meeting. The CME FedWatch tool calculates a 68% chance of action, based on trading in the Fed funds futures contracts.Carnage in the retail sector was Friday's big story. Nordstrom (JWN) was the disaster de jour, gapping down 15% in furious volume after reporting disappointing earnings and sales. Macy's (M) was down 2% and has lost nearly 19% this week on the heels of its own earnings disappointment.

Stocks were back near their session lows Monday afternoon after a rebound lost steam. The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were each off 1%. Volume was running mixed, with the Nasdaq tracking higher and the NYSE lower.
Stocks have been weak all day amid another big drop in oil prices. Crude oil for January delivery was near its session low, down nearly 5% to $38.03 a barrel.

Amid leading stocks, LGI Homes (LGIH) tumbled 7% in fast trade and breached its 50-day line earlier in the stock market today. LGI is now more than 20% off Wednesday's record high. But shares are still well extended from a 20.20 buy point from a flat base cleared in August.
Other leaders such as Dycom Industries (DY), NetEase (NTES) and Paycom Software (PAYC) were all off their session lows, but still down 1% to 2%.

On the upside, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) extended recent gains in the wake of last week's shooting in San Bernardino, Calif. Shares gapped up and rallied more than 7%, blowing through a 19.07 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The gun maker will report results for its fiscal Q2 after Tuesday's close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit surging 122% to 20 cents a share.
Shares of rival gun maker Sturm Ruger (RGR) were also up more than 7%. The stock cleared its 50-day and 200-day moving lines as a potential base forms.

But drought is only one of several plagues hanging over what is, far and away, South America's largest country…

In the stock market, big profits can be made if you know how to identify an industry disrupter in the early stages of its business. An industry disrupter is a company that comes to market with a new product or service that "disrupts" an existing market.In a 1995 essay titled "Disruptive Technologies: Catching the Wave," Harvard professors Clayton M. Christensen, regarded as one of the world's top experts on innovation and growth, and Joseph L. Bower wrote about how IBM (IBM) dominated the mainframe computer market in its early years but got left in the dust when Digital Equipment Corp. unveiled its minicomputers.DEC, in turn, mostly missed out on the personal computer market where Apple (AAPL) and other firms became dominant.Industry disrupters aren't exactly a dime a dozen, but examples aren't hard to find.It didn't take long for Amazon.com (AMZN) to disrupt the retailing industry. For years, Amazon spent heavily to build out its infrastructure. The investment is finally making its way to the bottom line as booming online sales continue to pose a big problem for large brick-and-mortar retailers.Tesla Motors (TSLA) arguably is an industry disrupter but not because of its cars. Carmakers aren't suffering because of Tesla's luxury electric vehicles. Many have lower-priced offerings of their own. The potential disruption lies in the battery business: With its $5 billion car battery gigafactory plant in Nevada, Tesla's goal is to reduce cell costs faster and produce more lithium-ion batteries by 2020 than were produced worldwide in 2013.And let's not forget about Netflix (NFLX), whose online streaming service is causing more and more consumers to "cut the cord" with cable TV operators.A lot of money has already been made in all three names, but the good news is that more will hit the market in coming months and years.The IPO market is always a hotbed for industry disrupters. Read the IPO Analysis column in Tuesday and Thursday's IBD to find potential stock ideas.While industry disrupters are always innovators, innovators aren't always industry disrupters. It's an important distinction. When automobiles were first introduced in America, they were expensive luxury items that did not immediately disrupt the market for horse-drawn vehicles.But when the lower-priced Ford Model T came to market in the early 1900s, the car turned into a disrupter.Many top-rated companies in IBD's database are innovating with new products or services, but most fall short of "industry disrupter" status. That's not a bad thing, though, because many stocks with high Composite, Earnings Per Share and Relative Price Strength ratings have new products or services that are fueling big earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. Those are catalysts for big price gains.

The stock market closed sharply lower Thursday, erasing about two weeks' worth of gains. The Nasdaq plunged 1.7%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average slid 1.4%. The Dow and S&P 500 closed below the 50-day moving averages.Volume rose on the Nasdaq and NYSE, according to unconfirmed figures.After the close, there was a bright spot as Ulta Beauty (ULTA) beat profit expectations. The retailer earned $1.11 a share, up 22%. Sales climbed 22% to $910.7 million.The company raised its forecast for the full 2015. It sees sales growth in the low 20% range, from previous guidance of a mid- to high-teens, and comparable-store sales gains of 10% to 11% from 8% to 10%. It also expects EPS growth in the low twenties vs. previous guidance of high teens. Shares rose more than 6% in extended trading.LGI Homes (LGIH), one of the winners in the IBD 50, plunged 11% in heavy volume, closing near its 50-day moving average. The homebuilder reported late Wednesday it closed on 249 homes in November 2015, up 51% from a year ago. It also announced 2,971 homes closed for the first 11 months of 2015, a 41% increase.A rise in oil prices helped the energy sector perform better than most. But it also caused truck and transportation equipment manufacturing stocks to be among the day's weakest. Apparel, biotech and some other medicals also were in the bottom rungs of the stock market today.The stock market has a major headline to watch Friday morning. The November employment report is out at 8:30 a.m. ET. Economists' consensus forecast is a gain of 190,000 jobs with the jobless rate staying at 5%, according to Econoday.Discount retailer Big Lots (BIG) is one of the few earnings reports due out Friday.

Never mind "Let It Snow." Heading into the crucial holiday shopping season, retailers are more likely singing "Let It Go" from the movie "Frozen" as they try to shake off disappointing quarterly earnings results and a bad week that collectively sank merchant stocks.Nordstrom (JWN), Macy 's (M), J.C. Penney Co. (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) were among those that reported the week of Nov. 9, with Nordstrom and Macy's turning in weak results and discounted forecasts, and J.C. Penney and Kohl's shares falling despite beating consensus views.An October retail sales data miss — a worse-than-expected 0.1% gain — didn't help either, though Amazon (AMZN) and other e-commerce sellers notably logged a 7.1% rise from the previous year as consumers continue to do much of their shopping online. Cowen & Co. predicted in July that Amazon would knock out Macy's as the top U.S. apparel retailer by 2017.Even much-lauded off-pricers haven't been immune to the pummeling that retail stocks were subjected to over the past week. Shares of TJX (TJX), the parent company of T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods, lost 12% over the past week.In a possible sign of things to come, Q3 same-store sales at Nordstrom's off-price arm, Nordstrom Rack, fell 2.2%."This type of miss from Rack is surprising to us, and we acknowledge the Rack's off-price slowdown could be a negative indicator for TJX," wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen on Friday.But he added that TJX, which reports Tuesday, could "offset some secular weakness" based on a few factors, including the strength of the company's sourcing and buying teams, home goods offerings and international reach.The company is expected to report a slight earnings dip of 1% to 84 cents a share. That would mark the third straight quarter of earnings deceleration and a swing from earnings gains of 7%, 8% and 15% in the three preceding periods.Revenue is seen rising 5% to $7.73 million, which also would reflect a slowdown.With a 75 IBD Composite Rating, TJX is the highest ranking member of IBD's Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group, which ranks a feeble 144 out of 197 groups.Peers in the group include Ross Stores, Foot Locker (FL), L Brands (LB) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO).Fellow off-pricer Ross Stores (ROST) gapped down ahead of its Thursday earnings release, losing 11% for the week. Analysts expect over 6% EPS growth to 50 cents on 6% sales growth to $2.77 billion.And what about the big-box retailers?Target's (TGT) earnings are seen accelerating, with a predicted 59% climb to 86 cents a share on a 1% revenue dip to $17.57 billion. Shares retreated 6.9% last week.And Wall Street expects Wal-Mart (WMT) earnings to slide 15% to 98 cents a share on a 1% revenue decline to $117.79 billion. Shares slid 4%."We believe retail is in a state of transition as brands wrestle with how to compete against growing & dynamic pureplay online retailers," wrote Chen.RELATED:Retail Sales Weak, Except For Amazon, EcommerceMacy's Stock Selloff Could Be Tip Of Iceberg4 Reasons TJX, Off-Price Retailers Will Keep Surging.

No single stock screen will be the best in every uptrend. Different uptrends reward different kinds of stocks, and the screens reflect that reality. For example, during the last bear market, the aggressive and growthy complexion of the IBD 50 (then the IBD 100) faded.Stocks making the list on Oct. 27, 2008, included El Paso Electric (EE), Campbell Soup (CPB), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).The mention of those equities alone said, "It's a bear market."As of early November, the 85-85 screen has been the top-performing screen over the past six months. The 85-85 was up 6.1%, while the S&P 500 gained 1.1% and the IBD 50 1.5%.What can be made of this? There are two ways to use a screen — the micro approach and the macro approach.The micro approach studies the list to find stocks that might be near buy points and that have few misses by CAN SLIM standards .The macro approach looks for patterns in the list. What kind of stocks are making the list — small caps or big caps? Which sectors or industry groups are plentiful? Are the stocks making the screen aggressive or defensive?Let's contemplate two screens — the IBD 50 and the 85-85, also known as Your Weekly Review in Friday's newspaper.Generally, the IBD 50 is a collection of stocks that have higher ratings than those in the 85-85 screen. Because the IBD 50 has higher ratings, these stocks should do better in a long and strong uptrend.Quality growth stocks, though, will likely correct more sharply than defensive stocks when the market runs into trouble.What is the advantage of the 85-85 screen?The 85-85 will pick up more turnaround stocks than the IBD 50. (A turnaround stock is less likely to have strong annual ratings over the past three years.) The 85-85's looser standard means that it's also more likely to pick up stocks benefiting from sector rotation. It also will pick up more small and thinly traded stocks than the IBD 50.The sector rotation angle has been apparent recently. Small bank and S&L industry groups accounted for 40 of the stocks in the 85-85 at the end of October.Yet only two bank stocks made the IBD 50 — Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and Signature Bank (SBNY). Many of the 85-85 bank stocks are thinly traded. Some, though, still attract quality mutual fund holders, as the table shows.
