Adobe Systems (ADBE) reported better-than-expected sales and earnings for its fiscal first quarter late Tuesday, but investors focused on one number that disappointed: new subscribers to Adobe's Creative Cloud.The media software company added 517,000 net new subscribers to its Creative Cloud, up 28% year over year and bringing the total to 3.97 million subscribers. But Wall Street analysts were looking for 573,000 additions for the quarter ended Feb. 27.Adobe stock was down 3.5%, below 77, in midday trading on the stock market today."We think it was a good number, but people would have liked to have seen more," Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett told IBD. "It was a really good quarter and if you're going to focus just on the 517 (thousand new subscribers), you're missing the bigger story anyway."Creative Cloud subscriber additions in Q1 were reduced by a reporting change, he said. With the launch of the company's new Document Cloud, Adobe is no longer lumping Acrobat subscribers in with Creative Cloud subscribers, he told IBD."That change had a significant impact on the subscriber number for Creative Cloud in the quarter," Garrett said.A better figure for investors to focus on is Adobe's annualized recurring revenue, he said. That number has been increasing since Adobe began its transition to an Internet cloud business model. Annualized recurring revenue reached $2.09 billion in Adobe's digital media businesses last quarter.Adobe's Q1 also showed that the company is becoming more profitable now that it is emerging from its transition from pay-upfront software to pay-as-you-go software."If you look at the revenue and earnings we generated this quarter, it really shows that the P&L is coming back in a very big way, which is terrific," Garrett said. "We're through the financial part of this transition."Adobe earned 44 cents a share, excluding stock-based compensation and other items, for its fiscal first quarter, up 46% from the year-earlier quarter. Sales rose 11% to $1.109 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Adobe to earn 39 cents a share on sales of $1.085 billion.For fiscal Q2, Adobe expects adjusted EPS of 44 cents on sales of $1.15 billion, at the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts were modeling 48 cents and $1.18 billion, but Adobe is known to be conservative with guidance.Adobe has three pillars to its cloud strategy: Creative Cloud, which includes creative professional software like Photoshop and Illustrator; Marketing Cloud, which provides online marketing tools; and Document Cloud, which extends Adobe's Acrobat and PDF standard."Adobe is an arms dealer to the creative and marketing worlds," Rosenblatt Securities analyst Kirk Adams said in a research note Wednesday. "The growth of the Creative Cloud and Marketing Cloud should provide investors with good returns over the next few years. We are excited to see revenues rebound this year as the transition to a mostly subscription and recurring revenue model is nearing completion."Adobe also is managing operating expenses tightly, which helps with earnings, he said. Adams rates Adobe stock as a buy.

With another Super Bowl comes another venerable tradition — the contest to produce the best ads. It's the biggest event of the advertising year — a 30-second Super Bowl XLIX ad will cost about $4.5 million — and represents one of the most significant opportunities for businesses to define themselves. The ads also highlight the ongoing struggle in corporate communications…

Hillary Clinton, the front-running presidential candidate who doesn't do interviews, finally sat down with CNN on Tuesday and said, "People should and do trust me."New York Times columnist Bill Safire must be rolling in his grave. A 1996 essay of his, "Blizzard of Lies," began, "Americans of all political persuasions are coming to the sad realization that our first lady — a woman of undoubted talents who was a role model for many in her generation — is a congenital liar."White House Press Secretary Mike McCurry responded: "The president, if he were not the president, would have delivered a more forceful response to that on the bridge of Mr. Safire's nose."Around the same time, Nebraska Sen. Bob Kerrey, a rival to Bill Clinton for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination, told Esquire that the president was "an unusually good liar. Unusually good. Do you realize that?"Safire would recognize the deceit underlying servergate as business as usual for the Clintons. The lies he catalogued back then included her phony explanation for a 10,000% profit in 1979 commodity trading, which "amounted to a $100,000 bribe"; the firing of White House travel aides, "who were then harassed by the FBI and Justice Department to justify patronage replacement by Mrs. Clinton's cronies"; and "lying when she denied actively representing a criminal enterprise known as the Madison S&L.""She is in the longtime habit of lying," Safire wrote nearly two decades ago, "and she has never been called to account for lying herself or in suborning lying in her aides and friends.""Trust me" is a game the Clintons have been playing for a long time.

NCR Corp.'s (NCR) stock on Tuesday spiked to a high not seen since October 2013 after Reuters reported that private equity giants Blackstone Group (BX) and Carlyle Group (CG) offered to jointly take over the firm in a $10 billion-plus leveraged buyout.

NCR makes ATMs, provides data services and began manufacturing some of the first mechanical cash registers in the 1880s. The company has reported EPS declines in three of the past five quarters and in its most recent quarter saw its quarterly revenue decline for the first time since at least 2011.

Shares of NCR Corp. bolted 10.6% to 34.70 on the stock market today. The stock briefly broke out from a cup-with-handle base at the beginning of this month but sagged back toward its 50-day and 200-day lines, where they have spent much of the past several months.

In making the offer, Blackstone and Carlyle would join a bidding war that includes Apollo Global Management (APO) and Thoma Bravo and others, sources told Reuters, adding that some of those suitors might also make joint bids.
An auction for NCR is "several weeks away from completion," Reuters said.

Carlyle shares edged up 0.6%, while Blackstone dipped 0.4%.NCR Corp.'s (NCR) stock on Tuesday spiked to a high not seen since October 2013 after Reuters reported that private equity giants Blackstone Group (BX) and Carlyle Group (CG) offered to jointly take over the firm in a $10 billion-plus leveraged buyout.NCR makes ATMs, provides data services and began manufacturing some of the first mechanical cash registers in the 1880s. The company has reported EPS declines in three of the past five quarters and in its most recent quarter saw its quarterly revenue decline for the first time since at least 2011.Shares of NCR Corp. bolted 10.6% to 34.70 on the stock market today. The stock briefly broke out from a cup-with-handle base at the beginning of this month but sagged back toward its 50-day and 200-day lines, where they have spent much of the past several months.In making the offer, Blackstone and Carlyle would join a bidding war that includes Apollo Global Management (APO) and Thoma Bravo and others, sources told Reuters, adding that some of those suitors might also make joint bids.An auction for NCR is "several weeks away from completion," Reuters said.Carlyle shares edged up 0.6%, while Blackstone dipped 0.4%.

Lawlessness: On Day 768 of the IRS scandal targeting political dissidents, the tax agency said it has more emails to release. Only it can't release them until September because it must ensure there are no duplicates. Baloney.Missing yet another court-ordered deadline on June 12, the Internal Revenue Service has failed to release 6,400 new emails found on the hard drive of Lois Lerner, former tax exempt organization chief, pertaining to the agency's admitted targeting of administration critics.The agency is being investigated by Congress and scrutinized by the group Judicial Watch.These are among the same emails whose release to congressional investigators had already been delayed by more than a year on errant claims by the IRS commissioner that the entire cache had been lost.Now, instead of that dog-ate-my-homework claim, the excuse is that the IRS only wants to make sure there are no duplicates in the bunch, a peculiar fastidiousness given how the agency has stopped answering most taxpayer phone calls .Let's cut to the chase here: The IRS is obstructing justice because it doesn't want the truth to come out . The agency has been caught red-handed targeting opponents of the Obama administration, including the tea party, pro-Israel groups and conservative news media.It purposely delayed issuances of tax-exempt status to nonprofit groups and held investigations entirely outside its own mandate.What the IRS is hiding is bound to be the work of malicious political operatives cloaking themselves as impartial civil servants, plotting among themselves against their political enemies through email.The stiff-arms given by the IRS at every juncture — from Lerner's invoking her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination at a House hearing to this latest claim about preventing duplicates — is consistent with that scenario.As a result, the IRS is moving closer and closer to rogue status — an agency so contemptuous of the law and confident of its impunity that it's becoming a law unto itself.Would the IRS itself be just as casual about deadlines if private citizens failed to file their taxes by April 15?Would it show understanding to a corporation that said it had lost all its emails with tax records in some sort of server crash that somehow wiped the whole thing clean?Does the IRS let anyone it has accused of tax evasion take the Fifth or withhold the incriminating evidence?Absolutely not. Yet it somehow expects the courts and Congress to go along with the sloppiness and obstruction it would never tolerate in the people it "serves."This raises questions about why the agency continues to escape justice. On Day 768 (as indefatigable TaxProf blog Professor Paul L. Caron has calculated) of this scandal, it's getting increasingly obvious that this agency intends to block any inquiry into its doings and avoid any accountability for its actions.It is dragging and delaying the process in hopes it will get a change of Congress or, better still, dogged investigators will lose interest. It's a war of attrition, a scorched-earth campaign, not just on dissidents but even more pointedly on the law itself.With each lawless act, the credibility of the agency is reduced and the case for the agency's abolition grows stronger. Already some presidential candidates, such as Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, are raising that possibility.If the IRS thinks it can just wait out and exhaust anyone seeking accountability and justice, it's likely to find itself in for a surprise. Justice's wheels turn slowly, but in the U.S. they eventually turn.It ought to think of itself as an institution instead of just a political arm of a party whose permanent hold on power is anything but certain.

Stocks were well off their lows at midday Tuesday after a jump in U.S. and European bond yields pointed to higher borrowing costs.

Just over two hours into the session, the Nasdaq was off 0.4%, the S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was running higher compared with the same time Monday.

The major averages were down as much as 1% early in the session after yields on 10-year U.S. and European bonds rose to their highest levels in five months. On Monday, the yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury note surged 13 basis points to 2.28%.
In the stock market today, Gap (GPS) fell 3% in heavy volume after the apparel retailer reported weaker-than-expected April same-store sales.

The Commercial Services-Outsourcing industry group was among the day's worst performing, weighed down by WageWorks' (WAGE) 17% plunge. Stifel Nicolaus cut its price target on the employee benefit provider to 55 from 66. WageWorks is 38% off its 52-week high after sinking below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

On the upside, managed health care stock Humana (HUM) was up 3% in heavy turnover. Retailers likely saw soft February sales gains as harsh winter weather, the West Coast port slowdown and foreign exchange headwinds dragged down results.

As of Wednesday, analysts were expecting February sales at stores open at least a year to rise 1.9% vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. The increase would be 6.1%, using Costco's U.S. forecast that excludes the drags of foreign exchange and lower gas prices.
The final tally for the month will be released Thursday.
Costco (COST) is expected to turn out a 0.9% rise in February same-store sales. But core U.S. same-store sales are seen rising 7.5%, backing out gas and foreign exchange headwinds.
Because shoppers fill their gas tanks as well as their shopping carts at Costco, the giant warehouse club is expected to be a significant drag on the overall sales data for February.
Costco will also report second-quarter earnings results on Thursday.
Foreign-exchange headwinds will weigh on Gap's (GPS) results, Perkins told IBD. The apparel retailer is forecast to show a 1.3% increase in February same-store sales.

Perkins adds that harsh winter weather likely "dampened spring selling in apparel and the West Coast port slowdown probably had an effect on inventory levels for some retailers that may have resulted in lost sales."
Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) is expected to see a 4.8% rise in same-store sales for the month.
Regional discount chain Stein Mart (SMRT) is projected to post a 3% increase, and teen retailer Buckle (BKE) is forecast to report a 0.1% rise.
PriceSmart (SMRT), which owns and operates U.S.-style membership shopping warehouses in Latin America and the Caribbean, is expected to see a 5.2% gain.
Drugstore operator Rite Aid (RAD) is seen showing a 4.6% increase.

But the weather should improve as we move into the spring, resulting in a sales pick-up, he notes. "I don't think we should read too much into a soft February. It's the smallest sales month of the first quarter."Retailers likely saw soft February sales gains as harsh winter weather, the West Coast port slowdown and foreign exchange headwinds dragged down results.As of Wednesday, analysts were expecting February sales at stores open at least a year to rise 1.9% vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. The increase would be 6.1%, using Costco's U.S. forecast that excludes the drags of foreign exchange and lower gas prices.The final tally for the month will be released Thursday.Costco (COST) is expected to turn out a 0.9% rise in February same-store sales. Just days after getting socked with a half-billion-dollar patent infringement penalty by a federal jury, Apple (AAPL) is facing fresh patent lawsuits.

On Tuesday, a jury in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas ruled that Apple's iTunes software infringed three patents held by patent licensing firm Smartflash. The federal jury ordered Apple to pay $532.9 million in damages.

On Wednesday, Smartflash decided to take another bite of the apple, suing the Cupertino, Calif.-based company for using the same patents without permission in devices introduced since the original case was filed in May 2013, Reuters reported. Those devices include the iPhone 6 series smartphones and iPad Air 2 tablet.
Proponents of patent reform called Smartflash a patent troll for using patents to shake down other companies for money instead of producing products.

"This case is Exhibit A for patent reform," Gary Shapiro, CEO of the Consumer Electronics Association, said in a statement. "The patent troll in this case doesn't produce any products and services, has zero employees and operates from an office across the street from the courthouse in the notoriously troll-friendly Eastern District of Texas.

"This sort of blatant patent extortion is exactly the reason why Congress needs to act now on patent reform. This is yet another of example of the tsunami of bogus patent claims that drain $1.5 billion a week from the U.S. economy. The only atypical aspect of this case is the defendant — the majority of patent troll victims are small firms without big legal budgets, who can easily be coerced into a settlement."
On Friday, Swedish mobile telecom-gear maker Ericsson (ERIC) said it sued Apple for patent infringement involving Ericsson's wireless communications patents and other inventions.

Ericsson on Thursday filed two complaints with the International Trade Commission and seven complaints in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against Apple asserting 41 patents covering many aspects of Apple's iPhones and iPads. The patents include standard essential patents related to the 2G and 4G/LTE standards as well as patents critical to the features and functionality of Apple devices, such as chip design, user interface software, location services and applications, and the iOS operating system.
Ericsson is seeking exclusion orders in the ITC proceedings and damages and injunctions in the federal court actions.

"Apple's products benefit from the technology invented and patented by Ericsson's engineers," Kasim Alfalahi, chief intellectual property officer at Ericsson, said in a statement. "Features that consumers now take for granted — like being able to livestream television shows or access their favorite apps from their phone — rely on the technology we have developed. We are committed to sharing our innovations and have acted in good faith to find a fair solution. Apple currently uses our technology without a license and therefore we are seeking help from the court and the ITC."

As the multibillion-dollar market for military and commercial drones gains traction, Lockheed Martin (LMT) and Raytheon (RTN) are just two firms that could benefit from the State Department's newly announced policy on expanding drone exports to allies.On Tuesday, the Obama administration established new standards for the global export of the unmanned devices that include strict sale conditions and "end-use assurances" from recipient nations.The new policy, which prohibits the use of American drones for "unlawful surveillance," opens the door to U.S. drone and arms manufacturers looking to make sales abroad.According to Reuters, the U.S. has sold armed drones to the U.K., while unarmed U.S. military drones have been sold to countries like France and Italy. The State Department will now review requests for armed drones from Italy and Turkey.Lockheed could notably stand to gain from increased drone exports: the General Atomics' Predator and Reaper drones use Lockheed missiles.The State Department's decision could also boost makers of drone components."Additional sales of Reapers to international users would benefit Raytheon, maker of the MTS-B multispectral targeting sensor, and L-3 Communications (LLL), which provides satellite communications components and training simulators," said Guggenheim Partners' Roman Schweizer in a note. "Honeywell (HON) supplies turboprop engines and guidance components."Lockheed shares were down 0.2% on the stock market today. L-3 dipped 0.4%, Honeywell rose 0.5%, and Raytheon eased 0.6%.Northrup Grumman (NOC), which makes the Global Hawk drone, and General Atomics, a privately held spinoff of General Dynamics (GD), were part of a growing chorus that reportedly had been pushing the U.S. government for more lenient export rules prior to Tuesday's announcement.Meanwhile, the FAA's proposed regulations for flying commercial drones in U.S. airspace have come under fire.Under draft rules, drones would not able to fly over people and must weigh less than 55 pounds, among other restrictions, preventing retailers like Amazon (AMZN) from making commercial drone deliveries. Companies currently authorized by the FAA to fly drones in the country include Trimble Navigation (TRMB) and AeroVironment (AVAV).

The health care and technology sectors in the S&P 500 have the highest percentage of companies reporting fourth-quarter earnings above analyst consensus estimates.In the health care sector, 91% of companies have beat the consensus estimates of analysts polled by FactSet Research. The information technology sector was right behind at 88%.The utilities sector leads on revenue beats, at 80%, followed by health care.The largest EPS beat came from Netflix (NFLX), followed by Amazon.com (AMZN) and Marathon Petroleum (MPC) .To date, the market is rewarding upside earnings surprises more than average and punishing downside earnings surprises less than average, FactSet said.Netflix stock jumped 17% after the video services provided reported Q4 earnings on Jan. 20. Amazon stock rose 14% after its earnings report Jan. 29. FactSet puts both companies in its "consumer discretionary" sector.In the information technology sector, Juniper Networks (JNPR) had the best earnings surprise, followed by KLA-Tencor (KLAC) and Electronic Arts (EA).The health care sector overall is reporting the highest earnings growth rate among S&P 500 companies, at 21.4%. Gilead Sciences (GILD) is the largest contributor to earnings growth for the sector.With 391 of the S&P 500 companies having reported December-quarter results, 77% have reported EPS above estimates. That's above the five-year average. The percentage of companies reporting revenue above estimates is 59%, and FactSet says that's slightly below the five-year average.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter: @IBD_BDeagon.

Apple (AAPL) might be getting ready to follow rival Samsung's lead in using organic light-emitting diode (OLED) displays for its smartphones.Apple currently uses liquid crystal display (LCD) screens for its iPhones. But OLED displays are thinner and more power-efficient, and have higher color saturation than LCDs. OLED displays are also flexible.Apple's first product to use an OLED display is the Apple Watch, which hit the market on April 24. Teardowns show that the smartwatch uses an active-matrix OLED display from LG Display (LPL).Shares of OLED technology firm Universal Display (OLED) hit a more than three-year high on Friday, closing up 1.7% at 53.46. The stock rose on speculation that Apple will soon start using OLED displays in its next-generation iPhone handset and iPad tablet, Zacks Equity Research said Thursday. Universal Display licenses its technology to LG Display, Samsung, AU Optronics (AUO) and other companies.If the rumors are true, one question is: When will Apple switch to OLED from LCD for iPhones and iPads?With the next version of the iPhone due out in September, the change might not happen until 2016, the Motley Fool suggested.Smartphones with OLED displays include the Samsung Galaxy S6 and Galaxy S6 Edge, LG G Flex 2 and Lenovo's Sisley S90, Motorola Moto X and Motorola Droid Turbo.RELATED:Apple Watch gross margins will start low but then rise.

Imagine a PGA tour where the world's best golfers earn a pittance for endorsement deals. Mark McCormack couldn't. In 1959 the Cleveland attorney was moonlighting as a tournament organizer when he overheard players complaining about how little money they were earning.Few were as frustrated as Arnold Palmer, golf's top player and arguably the nation's most exciting athlete, who landed a whopping $500 and all the ketchup he could eat for pushing the Heinz condiment."Appalling," McCormack said.The game was about to change.After hooking up with Palmer in late '59, McCormack set out to prove that corporations would pay enormous sums for celebrity athletes to endorse their products.In his first two years with McCormack, Palmer's annual earnings skyrocketed from $60,000 to $500,000.By 1967, the golfer's businesses, under McCormack's management, were ringing up sales of $15 million, worth $100 million today.Using Palmer as his springboard, McCormack (1930-2003) went on to create the International Management Group, a billion-dollar firm that represented a stable of sporting legends from Bjorn Borg and Jean-Claude Killy to Tiger Woods and Derek Jeter.By the time McCormack died, his Cleveland-based company had 80 offices in 32 countries employing almost 3,000 people.Rich LegacyForbes magazine estimated his net worth at $1 billion.Over the course of his groundbreaking career, Golf magazine called McCormack "the most powerful man in golf."Tennis magazine said he was "the most powerful man in tennis."Sports Illustrated cited him as "the most powerful man in sports."And the Times of London noted he was "one of the 1,000 people who have most influenced the 20th century.""I don't think it's an overstatement to say that kind of like Henry Ford and Bill Gates, Mark McCormack literally created and fostered and led an entirely new worldwide industry," CBS (CBS) Sports Chairman Sean McManus said following McCormack's death.McCormack was born in Chicago, the only child of a farm journal publisher. Mark's self-discipline came from his German-Irish mother, who always laid out breakfast the night before and planned her family's day to the split second.Mark was just 6 when he was hit by a car and suffered a fractured skull. His doctors said that contact sports like football and basketball were out, so he turned to golf.A steady player, he won the Chicago high school title and went on to play No. 1 at William & Mary.During a match with Wake Forest, he met Palmer, the star of the Wake Forest Demon Deacons.After graduation from Yale Law School and a hitch with the Army, McCormack joined a Cleveland law firm but walked away after his handshake deal with Palmer."He was an old-school businessman whose word was his bond," Jon Franklin, CEO of Glory Sports International and a former agent with IMG, told IBD. "You could do a deal on a napkin, and he'd stick by his word."After starting IMG in 1960, McCormack quickly snared lucrative exhibitions and endorsements for Palmer, who won the U.S. Open that year. As reigning champ into 1961, Arnie endorsed L&M; cigarettes on one of the first TV commercials to use an athlete.In short order, McCormack also signed a talented South African newcomer by the name of Gary Player and a young American professional called Jack Nicklaus.The Big Three dominated golf for the next decade. With McCormack netting them big deals, money poured in for everything from appearance fees to corporate outings."He realized how much sports were part of the culture," said Kirstin Kay, archivist at the Mark H. McCormack Department of Sport Management at the University of Massachusetts. "He realized there was a real entertainment factor."In 1968, McCormack went international, signing Killy after the French skier won three gold medals in the Winter Olympics.A year later, McCormack added Australian tennis champion Rod Laver and Scottish race car driver Jackie Stewart."I could have stayed with the big three golfers, as Col. Parker did with Elvis Presley, or take the idea into other sports," McCormack told the London Sunday Times. "I signed up Stewart, Laver and Killy. After that, people started coming to me, because the market was crying out for someone like me, and I seemed to be the only one with a track record."At the same time, McCormack began opening offices in Tokyo, Australia, South Africa and across Europe — establishing a foreign beachhead long before global trade was much discussed. "He was willing to go into markets and stay the course even while losing money for years," Franklin said.TV VisionMcCormack was one of the first to merge the rapidly growing TV industry with the sports world, increasing the marquee value of his athletes and such historic sporting events as tennis' Wimbledon and golf's British Open.His broadcast division was the largest producer of televised sports programming, other than the networks, and the largest seller of sports TV rights. To gain more exposure for his clients, he created events such as "The Superstars" (1973-2003) and "World's Strongest Man," which debuted in 1977."He created new ways to capitalize on what was then new media," Franklin said. "He saw very quickly that to get deals for his clients, he needed to get them exposure on television. Once you start creating these events, they have to be on television. So he created a television division."Into the 1980s, IMG expanded again, branching out to represent authors, classical musicians, fashion models, even the pope. "He led a very driven life," Kay said. "He was incredibly tightly managed."To keep pace with his business demands, he ran his life with military precision, rising at 4:30 a.m. and scheduling every moment of his day, including naps, exercise and playtime with his three children. He allowed only four hours a day for rest, trained himself to go to sleep as soon as he got into bed and kept his watch 10 minutes fast so as to be punctual for meetings. "He would say, 'In six months' time, on September 2 at 10:00, I'll call you,'" Killy said. "Six months later at 10:00 he'd call, on the nose."On The GoAll of his ventures made McCormack a prolific traveler, logging up to 200,000 miles a year, nearly all on commercial airlines.Though he had homes in New York, London, Cleveland and Orlando, Fla., half his time was spent in places where he had no home.In one two-month period in 1994, he was in London; Geneva; Zurich; Singapore; New York; Cleveland; Chicago; Los Angeles; St. Andrews, Scotland; Tokyo; Mexico City; Williamsburg, Va.; Orlando; Jakarta, Indonesia; and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.He kept busy during his travel by writing books, many on management, including "What They Don't Teach You at Harvard Business School," a best-seller in 1984.McCormack went all over with stacks of index cards, which he used to jot down everything from notes on people and projects to his exercise and sleeping habits. "His three-by-fives were about the best in the world," Palmer said. "He could pull a three-by-five out and tell you how many pushups he did 10 years ago or how many situps."McCormack's first marriage, in 1954 to Nancy Breckenridge, ended in divorce after three children. A second marriage came in 1986, to the tennis player Betsy Nagelsen, twice an Australian Open doubles champion, and they had a daughter.A year after McCormack died at age 72, Forstmann Little, a private equity firm, bought IMG for $750 million. In 2013 the company sold IMG to the entertainment talent agency William Morris Endeavor and private equity firm Silver Lake Partners for $2.3 billion.Despite the changes in ownership, McCormack's legacy as the godfather of sports marketing remains intact, 55 years after his landmark handshake with Palmer."I had luck," McCormack told London's Sunday Times. "I saw those two big things (television and high-profile athletes), and suddenly everybody started relating to sports. It was an easy sell. As stupid as it may seem today to say that Tiger Woods wearing Nike (NKE) can make a lot of money for Nike, people weren't doing that then."

Advance Auto Parts' (AAP) recent streak of robust sales growth is expected to hit the brakes this week when it reports Q1 results, as the auto parts retailer faces tougher comparisons to the prior year, when it benefited from a major buyout.

Advance Auto is due to report first-quarter results before the open on Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings of $2.49 a share, up 11% from the prior year. Sales are seen rising 3% to $3.05 billion, which would be the slowest gain in two years. It would also end a run of four straight quarters of 47%-or-better sales growth.

The company's results last year got a big lift from its January 2014 buyout of Genuine Parts for $2 billion. Full-year sales in 2014 climbed 49% — well above the 5% gain reported in 2013 and the 1% increase in 2012. EPS grew 21% in 2014.

Analysts expect Advance Auto to keep producing double-digit EPS growth over the next several years. The company has a strong IBD Composite Rating of 92. Its stock trades near 152 and is up about 6% since the beginning of May.
The company belongs to IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Auto Parts group, which ranks No. 43 out of 197 industries tracked. Other leaders include O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), AutoZone (AZO) and LKQ (LKQ).

The group has benefited in recent years from an aging fleet of cars on the road, which increases demand for replacement parts and repair work. More recently, lower gas prices have provided another boost.

In addition to selling auto parts to consumers as part of the do-it-yourself (DIY) market, Advance Auto and other auto parts chains operate do-it-for-me (DIFM) units that supply wholesale parts to mechanics and auto shops and provide in-house auto repair and maintenance services.

Advance Auto's DIFM same-store sales have kept pace with peers, though the company has launched several initiatives to improve the performance. After-hours earnings results, buyout buzz and a lawsuit settlement were the catalysts for stock gains and losses for big-name companies late Wednesday, including Salesforce.com (CRM), Williams-Sonoma (WSM), CVS Health (CVS) and Halliburton (HAL).
 Salesforce.com topped first-quarter estimates as adjusted earnings jumped 45% to 16 cents and sales climbed 23% to $1.51 billion.

The provider of customer relationship management software expects Q2 adjusted EPS of 17 cents to 18 cents vs. forecasts for 17 cents. Salesforce.com's Q2 revenue expectation of $1.59 billion to $1.6 billion beats Wall Street's predictions for $1.58 billion.
Shares popped 6.6% after the bell. If that trend continues into Thursday's regular session, shares could potentially be back in buy range from a flat base with a 71.10 buy point.
 Williams-Sonoma reported Q1 earnings that came in flat at 48 cents per share, topping estimates by 4 cents. Revenue rose almost 6% to $1.03 billion, above consensus expectations for $1.01 billion.
Comparable brand revenue increased 4.6% in the quarter, with Williams-Sonoma's West Elm furniture store chain leading the way with 15.3% comp growth.
Shares pushed up 4% late. The home furnishings retailer is working on a flat base with an 84.85 buy point.

 Design software maker Synopsys (SNPS) said that its fiscal Q2 EPS rose 5% to 68 cents while revenue increased 7.6% to $557.2 mil. Both topped expectations. For Q3, Synopsys sees earnings of 58-60 cents a share, short of Wall Street views for 66 cents.
Shares sank 1.5% after hours. Shares have been trading in buy range from a flat base with a 47.47 buy point for the past nine straight sessions.
 L Brands (LB) reported first-quarter earnings that grew 13% to an adjusted 61 cents, topping Wall Street calculations by a penny. Revenue climbed 5% to $2.51 billion, below expectations.
L Brands' Q2 EPS guidance of 60-65 cents was also short of estimates for 69 cents.
Shares dipped 0.9% in extended trading. The stock has been building a flat base with a 95.88 buy point.
 NetApp (NTAP) missed fiscal Q4 expectations as earnings fell 23% and revenue dropped 7%. The data storage firm also issued weak Q1 guidance.
Shares tumbled 7.9% after the bell. NetApp is trading below its 50-day and 200-day lines and is about 19% off of a 43.75 high set last September.
 CVS Health is in advanced talks to buy Cincinnati-based pharmacy distributor Omnicare (OCR), according to Bloomberg News sources.

With a market cap of $9.2 billion, Omnicare has been rallying over the past month amid talk of a takeover. Shares are approaching the 20% profit-taking zone from a flat base buy point of 79.80, which it initially cleared on April 21.
CVS shares got a 0.2% bump late after closing down 1%.
 And oil-field services firm Halliburton reached a settlement with BP (BP), resolving issues related to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon Gulf oil spill. Terms were not disclosed.
Shares edged down 0.4% after hours, while BP was little changed.

Stocks overcame a midday bout of the jitters to post a strong afternoon rally and close near the top of the day's trading range, breaking a six-day losing streak.
The Dow Jones industrial average's 619-point gain was the index's third highest point gain ever.
Only Oct. 13 and 28, 2008, were bigger. In percentage terms, however, it doesn't rate.
The Nasdaq rose 4.2%, the S&P; 500 gained 3.9% and the Dow was up 4% in the stock market today. Volume was higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq exchange, according to preliminary data.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 49 were higher and one was lower. The best performer was Google (GOOGL), up nearly 8% on a Goldman Sachs upgrade. The worst performer was Universal Insurance (UVE), down more than 3%.
Amazon.com (AMZN) rallied more than 7%, finding support at its 10-week line. Netflix (NFLX) also found support at its 10-week line, with an 8.5% advance.
Before the open Thursday, the Labor Department will report jobless claims for the week ended Aug. 22. The consensus among economists is for 270,000 new claims for unemployment.
Preliminary real GDP for the second quarter is expected to grow 3.2%. The GDP price index is expected to come in with a 2% increase.

While energy stocks have been pummeled, shares of pipeline operator EQT Midstream Partners (EQM) have been far more steady. The company last week reported Q4 earnings that topped Wall Street's expectations.
Profit of $1.12 a share marked an 81% increase over the year-earlier period. Its earnings growth is accelerating as the company adds assets. EPS climbed 37% and 42% in the previous two quarters.

The limited partnership was formed by EQT (EQT) to provide natural gas transmission, storage and gathering services in the Appalachian region, freeing EQT to focus on its oil and natural gas operations.
So how has EQT Midstream been able to keep its profits humming? The short answer is that its business is insulated from oil and gas prices.

The transmission side of the company generates revenues from firm, fixed-fee contracts, Senior Vice President of Midstream and Commercial Operations Randall L. Crawford explained in the Q4 earnings call. Under the contracts, "EQM gets paid regardless of whether the shipper uses them or not."
Ten-year firm capacity-reservation commitments support EQT Midstream's Jupiter Gathering System, which it acquired from EQT last year.

"I believe that, based on our existing contract terms and our backlog of organic growth projects, both the transmission and gathering sides of our business are very well positioned for continued success despite the recent drop in commodity prices," Crawford said.
The stock has been forming a base for more than seven months. A buy point is not obvious so far. The base is a risky late-stage pattern.

Yet the stock has displayed remarkable resilience, and its chart is one of the most attractive in the pipeline industry group. In fact, EQT Midstream's chart is in better shape than its parent EQT's. EQT is much deeper into a price decline than EQT Midstream.

And EQT Midstream's profit performance (it has a highest-possible EPS Rating of 99) compares favorably with its peers.While energy stocks have been pummeled, shares of pipeline operator EQT Midstream Partners (EQM) have been far more steady. The gross profit margin for the Apple Watch is below Apple's (AAPL) company average but has the potential to well exceed that average, UBS said in a research report Wednesday.

Based on a teardown analysis of the smartwatch, UBS estimates that the product's gross margin initially will be about 34% but could rise to 57% when it hits an annual volume of 40 million to 50 million units. UBS is modeling for 31 million units in fiscal 2016, which starts Sept. 27.
Apple said that it expects the Apple Watch's gross margin will be below the corporate average of about 39% in the June quarter. Apple's gross margin was 40.8% in the March quarter.

"Over time we expect Watch margins to be accretive and possibly the highest of any hardware offering, even with our analysis excluding likely highly profitable Edition models and band sales," the equity research firm said.

UBS estimates the initial gross margin on the entry-level Sport version of the Apple Watch to be 21% to 23%, including start-up costs. It estimates the midrange Apple Watch to have a margin above 45%.
UBS predicts that Sport models will make up 65% of Apple Watch sales, with midrange watches at 35% and luxury Edition models at a fraction of sales.

"CEO Tim Cook has said he has never seen accurate cost estimates for new products, perhaps because many analyses focus on component costs and overlook overhead costs," UBS said. "For example, we estimate non-BoM (bill of materials) costs represent 47% of total unit costs, heavily burdened with startup expenses, yield loss and conservative accrual assumptions."
UBS took apart a midrange Apple Watch with a 1.7-inch display, sapphire cover and stainless steel case, which retails for $599. It determined a bill of materials for the watch to be $134.

UBS identified USI Shanghai as the assembler of the main Systems-in-Package, which includes the application processor, memory and connectivity. This core system accounts for 31% of the total bill of materials.

It also identified LG Display (LPL) as the maker of the OLED display, TPK for the touch module, Broadcom (BRCM) for connectivity, Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM) for the heart rate monitor, and Analog Devices (ADI) for the touch panel controller. AAC Technologies and Nidec (NJ) are splitting the supply for the haptic motor.
Other Apple Watch component suppliers include NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and STMicroelectronics (STM).
RELATED:

Sometimes a stock will throw investors for a loop by rushing straight into new high ground without pausing to form a handle. Should investors be ready to step up and buy into this aggressive price action? While the cup with handle is one of the most common winning chart patterns, the related and more rare cup without handle is also worthy of study.

In general, the handle is an important part of a base, serving as a final shakeout and setting a lower, less obvious buy point. But there are enough examples of successful cup-without-handle breakouts to serve as a model for buying this setup.

Cups without handles tend to be more failure-prone because they have taken less time to digest gains from the stock's climb up the right side of the base. Yet they can still produce worthwhile gains. The entry point in a cup base is 10 cents above the high of the left side of the pattern.

A proper cup base should have many of the same positive characteristics as a cup with handle. Look for signs of strong institutional accumulation, such as weeks closing higher in above-average turnover and tight weekly closes.

Look for symmetry. Even though the stock doesn't shape a handle, the right side should still be roughly symmetrical to the left side. Bases that climb rapidly from the bottom to new highs in a compressed amount of time carry more risk.

In the late 1960s, Loews (L) built a giant cup without a handle before going on a massive run. The company was a beneficiary of the "follow-on effect," which is when a major development in one industry later has a spillover effect on a related industry.

During this period, the airline industry experienced rapid growth and stock price appreciation due to the introduction of jet airplanes. A dramatic increase in air travel led to increased demand for hotels and a huge run for Loews stock, which was using its theater land to build hotels in cities.

Loews' cup base was carved out during the 1966 bear market, causing the pattern to be unusually deep and large. It corrected 47% over 45 weeks, reasonable in the context of the Dow Jones industrials' 27% swoon.

Volume surged in the week of the March 1967 breakout to the highest level in years, showing overwhelming demand at the entry point. The stock's relative strength line (not shown on the chart) was hitting new highs as the stock outperformed the market despite its deep correction.
The stock ran out of the gate quickly and triggered the eight-week hold rule by climbing more than 20% past a 39.10 buy point in three weeks.
Following the rule helped keep investors in the stock through a sharp 14% pullback (1) and recovery.
Thirteen months later, after an approximate 300% price gain, the stock broke out from a smaller, eight-week cup-without-handle base (not shown) and climbed even higher before topping.
For a current example, pull up a chart of IBD 50 stock Lannett (LCI).

The generic-drug maker broke out past a 59.54 cup-without-handle buy point on Feb. 17. Shares advanced just a touch below 20% from the buy point last week before pulling back.Sometimes a stock will throw investors for a loop by rushing straight into new high ground without pausing to form a handle. Rumors of a big-screen iPad perked up this week with a report that Apple (AAPL) hopes to use a new type of touch panel for the jumbo-size tablet.Citing unnamed sources in the supply chain, Korea IT News reported Monday that Apple has requested silver nanowire display samples from LG Display (LPL), Samsung Display and others for the so-called iPad Pro tablet, AppleInsider reported Monday.The silver nanowire touch display would be more flexible than current displays and could enable the deployment of Force Touch technology. Apple uses Force Touch in the Apple Watch to distinguish between different touches like a tap and a press. Apple is rumored to be looking to add Force Touch to its next smartphone, the iPhone 6S, this fall.The iPad Pro would have a 12.9-inch display, vs. the 9.7-inch display of the current iPad. It might even use a stylus for applications that involve writing, drawing or annotating.That development would put the iPad Pro in direct competition with Microsoft's (MSFT) Surface Pro 3, a 12-inch tablet that converts to a notebook when connected to a thin and lightweight keyboard accessory. Microsoft is expected to announce a follow-on product, the Surface Pro 4, this summer, timed with the release of Windows 10.The iPad Pro might not be released until 2016, AppleInsider said.Apple is looking for ways to lift its sagging iPad sales. The company has teamed with IBM (IBM) to develop enterprise applications for the tablet.RELATED:Apple iPad, Tablets' Best Growth Years Are History.

Small-cap stocks are risky bets when interest rates rise, according to many investors. Rising rates challenge their financial resources more than large caps' resources. Also, rising rates boost their borrowing costs. The Federal Reserve would like to start raising interest rates back toward normal levels when it can, though so far a tepid economy keeps thwarting its plans.
But many small-cap stocks are better positioned to withstand eventual rate hikes than they were during past hikes. Savvy investors can take advantage of that fact.

"What's different this cycle is that corporate balance sheets are lean, especially for small caps," said Eric Marshall, a manager of several top mutual funds from the Hodges complex, including the $2 billion Small Cap Fund .

"Small caps have not levered themselves up to make acquisitions and stock buybacks as much as large caps have," he added. "And few have (heavy exposure) to floating rate interest like they did in the 1980s and '90s."

In addition, rising rates should help boost the value of the dollar. And a rising dollar should hurt small caps less than large caps because small caps generally get less of their revenue and earnings from exports.
The dollar surged from May to March but has slid as rate rises became less imminent.
Favoring Financials
When interest rates do start to rise, some businesses stand to benefit in the stock market. Many are in financial services.
Rising rates should allow smaller banks to boost the interest rates that they charge for loans, Marshall says. Meanwhile, their own costs of capital will remain low.
One name he likes in that space is Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI).

For the same reasons, Scott Tracy, a manager of $2.2 billion RS Small Cap Growth , likes Western Alliance Bancorp (WAL). It is in markets, like Nevada and Arizona, that are recovering. And it is acquiring Bridge Capital (BBNK), gaining exposure to the Silicon Valley market.

Tracy also likes SVB Financial (SIVB), the parent of Silicon Valley Bank, which operates in its namesake area as well as China, Hong Kong, India, Israel and the U.K. "North of 80% of its business is in adjustable rates, so its spreads should widen as rates rise," he said.
PrivateBancorp (PVTB) has 95% of its loans tied to adjustable rates. "If rates go up, their loan yields will expand," Tracy said.

Andrew Morey, manager of $124 million Aston/LMCG Small Cap Growth , likes Evercore Partners (EVR), which he calls an advisory M&A boutique bank. It could benefit from a spike in acquisitions by larger companies as rates rise.
The start of rate hikes could trigger takeovers. "A lot of corporate CFOs might want to borrow for M&As while rates are still relatively low," Moray said.
Among stocks impacted by the strengthening dollar, Tracy likes WisdomTree Investments (WETF).
As the dollar has strengthened, WisdomTree has benefited from its currency-hedged ETFs. "People have flocked to their products as the dollar rose," he said.

Marshall points out that rising rates would be a sign that the Fed believes that U.S. GDP growth is gaining strength. In that case, builders of starter homes could benefit from an uptick in business. He likes LGI Homes (LGIH) and D.R. Horton (DHI). He also likes providers of building materials, including Eagle Materials (EXP) and Encore Wire (WIRE).Small-cap stocks are risky bets when interest rates rise, according to many investors. Rising rates challenge their financial resources more than large caps' resources. Also, rising rates boost their borrowing costs. The Federal Reserve would like to start raising interest rates back toward normal levels when it can, though so far a tepid economy keeps thwarting its plans.But many small-cap stocks are better positioned to withstand eventual rate hikes than they were during past hikes. Savvy investors can take advantage of that fact."What's different this cycle is that corporate balance sheets are lean, especially for small caps," said Eric Marshall, a manager of several top mutual funds from the Hodges complex, including the $2 billion Small Cap Fund ."Small caps have not levered themselves up to make acquisitions and stock buybacks as much as large caps have," he added. "And few have (heavy exposure) to floating rate interest like they did in the 1980s and '90s."In addition, rising rates should help boost the value of the dollar. And a rising dollar should hurt small caps less than large caps because small caps generally get less of their revenue and earnings from exports.The dollar surged from May to March but has slid as rate rises became less imminent.Favoring FinancialsWhen interest rates do start to rise, some businesses stand to benefit in the stock market. Many are in financial services.Rising rates should allow smaller banks to boost the interest rates that they charge for loans, Marshall says. Meanwhile, their own costs of capital will remain low.One name he likes in that space is Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI).For the same reasons, Scott Tracy, a manager of $2.2 billion RS Small Cap Growth , likes Western Alliance Bancorp (WAL). It is in markets, like Nevada and Arizona, that are recovering. And it is acquiring Bridge Capital (BBNK), gaining exposure to the Silicon Valley market.Tracy also likes SVB Financial (SIVB), the parent of Silicon Valley Bank, which operates in its namesake area as well as China, Hong Kong, India, Israel and the U.K. "North of 80% of its business is in adjustable rates, so its spreads should widen as rates rise," he said.PrivateBancorp (PVTB) has 95% of its loans tied to adjustable rates. "If rates go up, their loan yields will expand," Tracy said.Andrew Morey, manager of $124 million Aston/LMCG Small Cap Growth , likes Evercore Partners (EVR), which he calls an advisory M&A boutique bank. It could benefit from a spike in acquisitions by larger companies as rates rise.The start of rate hikes could trigger takeovers. "A lot of corporate CFOs might want to borrow for M&As while rates are still relatively low," Moray said.Among stocks impacted by the strengthening dollar, Tracy likes WisdomTree Investments (WETF).As the dollar has strengthened, WisdomTree has benefited from its currency-hedged ETFs. "People have flocked to their products as the dollar rose," he said.Marshall points out that rising rates would be a sign that the Fed believes that U.S. GDP growth is gaining strength. In that case, builders of starter homes could benefit from an uptick in business. He likes LGI Homes (LGIH) and D.R. Horton (DHI). He also likes providers of building materials, including Eagle Materials (EXP) and Encore Wire (WIRE).

Retailers likely kicked off the year with modest January sales gains as shoppers spent less freely after a holiday buying spree.As of Wednesday, analysts were expecting January sales at stores open at least a year to rise 3.1% vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics.The final tally for the month will be released Thursday."The estimate reflects a slowdown in spending post-holiday," Perkins told IBD. "But it doesn't suggest a slowdown in spending(generally) by any means. It's more a reflection of January being a clearance month and consumers taking a breather following the holiday and spending on other things such as cars."Consumers, he adds, "spent somewhat robustly" during the holiday.November-December combined same-store sales rose a healthy 5% vs. a year earlier.One drag on the January index came from Costco Wholesale (COST). The warehouse club giant and typical top retail performer posted flat January same-store sales Wednesday morning, well short of views for a 1.6% gain, as it got hurt by lower gas prices and foreign exchange headwinds amid a stronger U.S. dollar. Core U.S. same-store sales, backing out gas and foreign exchange headwinds, rose a healthy 7% vs. a year earlier, though shy of forecasts for a 7.9% increase."Given Costco's miss, which wasn't unexpected, it's unlikely (retailers) will beat expectations after exceeding estimates 10 of the last 11 months," said Perkins.On Jan. 29, drugstore operator Rite Aid (RAD) posted a 4.8% rise in January same-store sales, short of estimates for a 5% increase.Rival Walgreens (WBA) is expected to see a 6% gain in January same-store salesVictoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) is expected to see a 2% rise in same-store sales for the month.Major apparel retailer Gap (GPS) is forecast to show a 1.3% decline in January same-store sales.Regional discount chain Stein Mart (SMRT) is projected to post a 3.6% increase in January same-store sales.Teen retailer Buckle (BKE) is forecast to report a 2.8% rise in same-store sales for the month.PriceSmart (PSMT), which owns and operates U.S.-style membership shopping warehouses in Latin America and the Caribbean, is expected to see a 0.1% drop in January same-store sales.
L Brands (LB) reported Thursday that its sales for the month of March were positively impacted by the earlier Easter this year.
The parent of Victoria's Secret, Bath & Body Works and Henri Bendel said net sales for the five weeks ended April 5 increased 6% to $981.2 million.
Comparable store sales for the period jumped 9%, with a positive impact of 3 percentage points to 4 percentage points from the Easter holiday.
Retail Metrics had estimated L Brands to show a 5.8% rise in same-store sales for the month.
Shares fell 0.2% to 94.25 after initially climbing 1.2% to 95.65 on the stock market today.The stock is in buy range from a 94.94 flat base buy point.

L Brands has an IBD Composite Rating of 84 out of 99. That means its shares outperform 84% of all stocks on the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, profit margins, return on equity and relative price performance.

The Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group is ranked No. 34 out of the 197 industry groups that IBD tracks and is led by Ross Stores (ROST) (96 CR), Foot Locker (FL) (95 CR) and Lululemon (LULU) (95 CR).

After a solid holiday shopping season in which retailers benefited from lower gas prices and a recovering economy, January brought more upbeat news for the sector, especially among specialty chains like Ulta (ULTA) — an IBD Leaderboard stock — that were able to keep promotions down and traffic up.

In a new industry report, Sterne Agee analyst Ira Boruchow said retail's fiscal year — which wraps up in January for most retailers — "likely ended on a high note." Among the key takeaways for specialty retailers during the month:

 Improving customer traffic: Citing data from industry researcher ShopperTrak, Boruchow notes that while January store traffic was down year-over-year — part of an overall trend that has seen online shopping cut into mall traffic — apparel and accessories retailers did see an improvement from the overall trend in 2014.

"Same-store traffic was down 1.4% in January, but these results compare favorably to the average decline of 5% for the previous six months," Boruchow said. "When comparing traffic to the trailing 12 months, January was up 4.5%, a continuation of a positive trend."

 A slowdown in promotions: After coming off "one of the most promotional holiday and post-holiday seasons in recent years," Boruchow said, discounts for specialty retailers were "still elevated," though to a lesser degree, in January.
"Discounting still appears to be moderating sequentially," he noted.

While some specialty retailers — including Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) and Gap (GPS) — still discounted heavily in January, others like L Brands (LB) and Signet Jewelers (SIG) had an easier time selling at full price.

 "Restrained" markdowns at Ulta: The beauty and cosmetics chain has been one of the top performers in retail, with an IBD Composite Rating of 99 and a years-long run of double-digit sales and earnings gains.
In January, Boruchow said, Ulta ran about the same types of promotional events as it did the prior year.

"However," he added, "we believe that at the end of the month, the company was running fewer brand-specific and product-specific promotions, resulting in a net decrease in promotional activity in the final week of the month."

In addition to Ulta, another top stock in Sterne Agee's specialty retail universe is TJX Cos. Ewing, N.J.-based Universal Display (OLED) rocketed, then drifted back down like a signal flare early Monday, drawing attention to the LED lighting market.

Universal spiked 22% at the open, after announcing an eight-year licensing and supply agreement with South Korea's LG Display (LPL). The deal revolves around OLEDs — organic light emitting diodes that generate light via organic, rather than artificially manufactured, chemicals reacting with the current produced by the LED chips.
OLED fans say the technology allows thinner, higher resolution screens than technologies such as liquid crystal display designs using LED backlighting.

The deal underscores increasingly complex LED markets. Edwin Mok, analyst with Needham & Co., estimates LED market growth will slow to 10% this year after a 22% gain in 2014. In addition, overcapacity and a widening crowd of competitors are driving down prices and profit margins across the industry.

The LED market is home to familiar names including Cree (CREE) and Netherlands-based Koninklijke Philips (PHG). But China has funded a vast buildup of LED production capacity. LG also contends with South Korean compatriot Samsung Electronics, as well as Taiwan-based LED giants including Epistar (which scored $22.2 billion in 2013 revenue) and Everlight Technologies (2013 revenue of $24.7 billion).

Despite that backdrop, analysts expect LG Display's earnings to rise 33% in 2015. That's a steep slowdown from a forecast of 137% growth in 2014 (providing LG meets projections for a 622% gain in Q4). Sales, which have wobbled back and forth for the past four years, are expected to slip 3% in 2014, then rise 9% for 2015.

The company's American depositary shares trade an average 310,000 shares a day. That is fairly strong for a non-U.S. issue. Those shares have seen a sharp uptick in accumulation over the past three weeks, leaving it with a strong Accumulation/Distribution rating of B+.

Maybe the most interesting element of LG Display is its chart. Shares are set up in a cup-with-handle base, just below a 16.92 buy point. The base formed immediately after the stock exited an almost two-year consolidation.

The stock's Relative Price Strength Rating is a comparatively weak 72 out of a maximum 99 score. The Nasdaq rose 0.3% as Internet, solar, fiber optic and software stocks were among the best performers in the stock market today.

If you've been trading options for any length of time, you've probably experienced some surprises in your P/L. When using options, changes in volatility and changes in prices can result in a quick profit or you could experience a quick loss. How do you handle this?
This is not an easy question to answer but there are step you can take to improve your results. Over the years, I've realized how important it is to understand and manage your risk.
Here are some steps to consider helping you manage your risk:

1) Always understand your overall POSITION risk —If you are establishing a position as an Iron Condor or a Credit Spread for example, your max loss is the width of your spread less the credit you receive. Sometimes when you establish a position, you can be far away price wise from the max loss, but always remember that a quick gap against you can get you to the max loss faster than you may think. If you are buying options or Debit Spreads your risk is normally limited to the amount you pay, but again make sure the amount you pay for the trade is not more than you are willing to lose if the trade goes against you. Whether selling or buying options, always know where your max risk and max loss points are (which is further explained in step 2).

2) What is your personal risk "limit"? — You should always know your max RISK vs your max LOSS on any trade. In most cases, your max RISK is not your max LOSS. For example, if you have max risk of $5000 on a trade, this may not mean you are willing to take a $5000 LOSS. You may be willing to take a $500 or a $1000 loss on a trade, but again your potential RISK may be $5000. There is a difference and you should always know your max LOSS point to close the trade and get out. You need to always have your personal number in your mind and be consistent with it. In other words, don't lose $500 on one trade and $10,000 on another. The way to be successful trading options is to strive for consistency. Don't let one trade blow you up.

3) How does each trade relate to your overall portfolio? This is something a lot of people don't seem to think about. If you have 10 trades in your options portfolio and they are all Bullish or all Bearish, your entire portfolio can get crushed by a big swing one way or the other. It is perfectly fine to "lean" your overall portfolio one way or the other based on your own personal market outlook, but ideally you may want a few trades that "offset" each other. For example, if you are going to use 10 total trades, it is not a bad idea to have 5 bullish and 5 bearish trades so that if the market goes up you make money and if it goes down, you can still make money.

4) How often will you be able to monitor your trades? This may sound like a straightforward question, but this can make a big difference in your results. If you are not able to watch the market during the day, try to use trades that are much further out in time (expiration). For example, you can use longer dated Iron Condors or Butterflies that won't react violently to gaps up or down in the market. If you can't watch the market closely, you should consider avoiding weekly options or very short term options. We all know how fast the market and our trade positions can change and if you are not watching, you may not have time to avoid a quick move and a quick loss.

5) Protect your Mental Capital — Generally when things are going well with the market, things are going well in your overall portfolio. On the other hand, when the market gets ugly, your entire portfolio can turn ugly quickly. It is best to cut your losers quickly and go to cash when this happens. In my experience, one of the worst things is to hold onto a losing trade and jeopardize your other positions. We tend to wait and hope the loser will get better and it takes your focus off your other positions that you may need to be managing. If you have a loser trade, and you find yourself lying in bed at night worrying about it, this is the time to cut it loose.

I have tried to cover some general concepts here that may help you to think about your risk in a different way and help you to be able to avoid some losses. Always remember that if you wake up at 4 o'clock in the morning in a cold sweat worrying about your options positions, you have a problem. Either you have too much overall at risk, you have too large a position or a general overall risk level too high in your portfolio. Options trading should be a fun and exciting experience, not a risky and terrifying one. Make your money work for you and not the other way around.

For more information about trading options visit: simpleroptions.com. If you've been trading options for any length of time, you've probably experienced some surprises in your P/L. Retailers likely saw flat April sales as an early Easter holiday dragged down results, leading to what could be the worst showing in years.
As of Wednesday, analysts were expecting April sales at stores open at least a year to remain flat vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics.
That would mean retailers will break a string of 67 straight months of same-store-sales growth dating back to August 2009.
"The biggest issue facing retailers is the shift in the Easter holiday sales out of April into March, which probably translated into a 3% to 5% drag on April same-store sales," Perkins told IBD.
Easter came on April 5 this year, while it fell on April 20 last year.
"Couple that with a difficult comparison with last year's Easter same-store sales growth of 6.2%, and that leads to what will likely be pretty soft sales results," he continued.

"I would not read too much into these results given the noise from the Easter holiday shift and the West Coast port delays. That puts the onus on May sales to snap back and show some signs of life. Better weather, pent-up demand, spring-related merchandise and improved economic conditions should drive stronger sales."

Warehouse club giant Costco Wholesale (COST) is estimated to see a 0.4% gain in April same-store sales. Core U.S. same-store sales are seen rising 5.1%, backing out of gasoline and foreign exchange headwinds.
Major apparel retail operator Gap (GPS) is seen posting a 7% decline in same-store sales for the month.
Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) is seen showing a 0.1% drop in same-store sales for the month, weighed down by the Easter holiday shift.
The company gets a Composite Rating of 82 from IBD out of a possible 99, based on several metrics such as earnings growth and stock price gains.
Drugstore operator Rite Aid (RAD) reported a 3% rise in April same-store sales over the prior year on April 30. That was ahead of views for a 2.3% gain. It has a Composite Rating of 81 from IBD.
Regional discount chain Stein Mart (SMRT), which holds a Composite Rating of 86, is projected to see a 0.8% decline in same-store sales.
PriceSmart (PSMT), which owns and operates U.S.-style membership shopping warehouses in Latin America and the Caribbean, is expected to see a 2.3% increase.

Teen retailer Buckle (BKE) is forecast to report a 4.7% decline in April same-store sales.Retailers likely saw flat April sales as an early Easter holiday dragged down results, leading to what could be the worst showing in years.As of Wednesday, analysts were expecting April sales at stores open at least a year to remain flat vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics.That would mean retailers will break a string of 67 straight months of same-store-sales growth dating back to August 2009."The biggest issue facing retailers is the shift in the Easter holiday sales out of April into March, which probably translated into a 3% to 5% drag on April same-store sales," Perkins told IBD.Easter came on April 5 this year, while it fell on April 20 last year."Couple that with a difficult comparison with last year's Easter same-store sales growth of 6.2%, and that leads to what will likely be pretty soft sales results," he continued."I would not read too much into these results given the noise from the Easter holiday shift and the West Coast port delays. That puts the onus on May sales to snap back and show some signs of life. Better weather, pent-up demand, spring-related merchandise and improved economic conditions should drive stronger sales."Warehouse club giant Costco Wholesale (COST) is estimated to see a 0.4% gain in April same-store sales. Core U.S. same-store sales are seen rising 5.1%, backing out of gasoline and foreign exchange headwinds.Major apparel retail operator Gap (GPS) is seen posting a 7% decline in same-store sales for the month.Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) is seen showing a 0.1% drop in same-store sales for the month, weighed down by the Easter holiday shift.The company gets a Composite Rating of 82 from IBD out of a possible 99, based on several metrics such as earnings growth and stock price gains.Drugstore operator Rite Aid (RAD) reported a 3% rise in April same-store sales over the prior year on April 30. That was ahead of views for a 2.3% gain. It has a Composite Rating of 81 from IBD.Regional discount chain Stein Mart (SMRT), which holds a Composite Rating of 86, is projected to see a 0.8% decline in same-store sales.PriceSmart (PSMT), which owns and operates U.S.-style membership shopping warehouses in Latin America and the Caribbean, is expected to see a 2.3% increase.Teen retailer Buckle (BKE) is forecast to report a 4.7% decline in April same-store sales.

The "Uncarrier"-branded promotions of T-Mobile US (TMUS) will deliver sustainable, positive free cash flow as it continues to gain subscribers despite fierce wireless competition, says Morgan Stanley, which rates T-Mobile a top global telecom stock pick along with Vodafone (VOD) and China Unicom (CHU).T-Mobile, controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), will eke out $47 million in free cash flow in 2015, estimates Morgan Stanley. Analyst Simon Flannery forecasts that T-Mobile will churn out $774 million in FCF in 2016, $1.68 billion in 2017 and $2.13 billion in 2018. Free cash flow is generally defined as cash from operations minus capital expenditures.T-Mobile's aggressive promotions have taken a toll on ARPU, or average revenue per user. But Flannery expects ARPU to stabilize."We believe there is more room for the Uncarrier initiative," said Flannery in a research report. "We are looking for ARPU stabilization, EBITDA growth and signs of positive free cash flow. T-Mobile has the most radio spectrum per subscriber, and has positioned itself as the customer-friendly carrier."T-Mobile on April 28 raised its 2015 guidance for postpaid subscriber additions after adding 991,000 phone customers in Q1, taking customers from AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ).T-Mobile's aggressive Uncarrier promotions, which started with equipment installment payment plans for mobile phones, spurred its subscriber growth in 2013 and 2014. EIP reduces upfront retail subsidies on mobile phones, while revenue is booked upfront. EIP offers usually come with discounts on data service, lowering ARPU.Morgan Stanley also rates Vodafone and China Unicom as top global telecom picks."We view Vodafone as the best way to play the three most important themes (in) the European sector: mobile data monetization, waning regulatory headwinds and market consolidation," said the report.Morgan Stanley's "least preferred" telecom picks include Sprint (S), America Movil (AMX) and India's Bharti.

The good news is that the series of earthquakes has been relatively minor — with the largest ranging in magnitude between…

Real estate investment trusts are outperforming in the stock market, up 8% this year as an IBD industry group after doubling the S&P 500's 11% gain in 2014. And factoring in dividends, REITs delivered a total return of 27.5% for the year, according to SNL Financial.One of the top-rated names in IBD's Finance-Property REIT group — which ranks No. 22 out of 197 industries tracked — is Pebblebrook Hotel Trust (PEB). It invests in upscale hotel and resort properties primarily in large U.S. markets.The company's portfolio tends toward four-diamond boutique hotels in big cities such as New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Boston and Washington. The AAA travel site defines four-diamond hotels as "upscale in all areas," with "an extensive array of amenities combined with a high degree of hospitality, service and attention to detail."Pebblebrook's properties include the Hotel Monaco in Seattle and Washington, D.C.; the Le Meridien Delfina in Los Angeles; the Westin Gaslamp in San Diego; the Sir Francis Drake in San Francisco; the InterContinental Buckhead in Atlanta; and the Affinity Manhattan in New York.Hot In HotelsThe company owns all or part of 35 hotels with a total of nearly 7,000 guest rooms and a 49% joint venture interest in six hotels with a total of 1,775 guest rooms.It boasts an IBD Composite Rating of 99, which puts it atop the Finance-Property REIT group along with Chatham Lodging Trust (CLDT), Extra Space Storage (EXR), Sovran Self Storage (SSS) and Sun Communities (SUI), among others.Like those companies, Pebblebrook has seen its share price hit record highs this month. The company is also in the middle of a long run of double-digit-percentage earnings and revenue gains, thanks to a mix of favorable macro trends and strong internal operations.On the macro side, the tourism industry in general and the hotel business in particular have gotten a boost from an improving economy, lower gas prices and an influx of visitors from overseas, particularly in large urban markets."The fundamentals are very good for the hotel industry right now, and they're improving," said Pebblebrook Chief Financial Officer Raymond Martz.Overall demand for U.S. hotel rooms in 2014 rose 4.5% from the prior year, he told IBD. "That's a very strong increase. At the same time, supply was only up 0.9%. So right now demand is very good."On the operational side, Pebblebrook boasts a "high-quality portfolio" and some of the highest room rates and revenue per available room (RevPAR) in the hotel sector, according to a recent note by Stifel Nicolaus analyst Rod Petrik.During its third quarter, Pebblebrook posted an 11.4% year-over-year increase in same-property RevPAR to $225.25 a day. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, same-property RevPAR climbed 9.8% from a year earlier.Those growth numbers are expected to decelerate this year as Pebblebrook focuses on integrating a handful of new properties. On Jan. 22 the company issued its 2015 outlook and guided same-property RevPAR growth of 6.5% to 7.5%.Pebblebrook focuses on buying underperforming hotels and turning them around. The company completed more than $600 million worth of acquisitions in 2014, Martz says."A lot of assets we buy are broken," he said. "In many cases they were mismanaged or are being renovated, or the prior owners lost their focus for whatever reason. So we work to renovate the hotels, reposition the room rates and make the properties appeal to a certain kind of traveler."Restoring GrandeurThe job involves "a lot of hard work and creativity," Martz says. "There's a lot more operating involvement vs. buying an office building and leasing it out for five years. You have to bring in the right food and beverage operator, create the right atmosphere."Pebblebrook's most recent deal came on Dec. 18, when it announced the acquisition of the Revere Hotel Boston Common, an attached, 826-space parking garage and an adjacent land parcel. That deal, for $260.4 million, brought the company a 356-room hotel in downtown Boston's historic Theater District.The Revere buyout came a week after Pebblebrook spent about $52 million to purchase the Union Station Hotel, a 125-room property in downtown Nashville, Tenn., that first opened in 1900 as the L&N Railroad Station. The property was converted to a hotel in 1986.Other recent deals include the Nov. 20 purchase of the Hotel Palomar Los Angeles-Westwood for $78.7 million and the Nov. 12 buyout of Miami's Westin Colonnade Coral Gables for $59.4 million.Looking For The GemsWhen pursuing acquisitions, Pebblebrook looks at properties "that can be positioned as four-diamond hotels," Martz said."We get hotels that cater to business travelers as well as high-end leisure travelers," he added. "About two-thirds are considered boutique hotels, and we have a lot of flexibility in tailoring those hotels to specific travelers."Pebblebrook's near-term expansion strategy will likely focus on West Coast markets because that's where most of the new supply is, he says.Analysts credit the company with doing a good job of turning acquired properties around."PEB has actively acquired hotels that lost market share due to the recession and has allocated capital ... to reposition these hotels to recapture market share," RBC Capital Markets analyst Wes Golladay noted in a research report.He says Pebblebrook's increased acquisition volume will be "a key driver of increased shareholder value."That value keeps going up. Pebblebrook shares touched a record high of 49.61 on Jan. 22 and have risen more than 60% over the past 12 months.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect GE to report a 4% rise in earnings to 55 cents per share. Revenue is seen climbing 4% to $42.12 billion. Some industry watchers are concerned that GE is too…
Stocks hit fresh session highs late Thursday and were on track for a fourth straight gain.

Helped by Internet and computer hardware stocks, the Nasdaq rallied 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 1%. Volume was tracking modestly higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today

Tata Motors (TTM) stretched its gain to 3%. Earlier, the stock cleared a 48.28 buy point in a double-bottom base in heavy trading. The Indian carmaker has a Composite Rating of 83, the highest in the Auto Manufacturers group. Tata was mentioned in International Leaders earlier this month.

Under Armour (UA) rallied 3% and regained its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is in a flat base within a larger pattern. Telsey Advisory Group upgraded shares to outperform from market perform Wednesday.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) reversed and fell 2% ahead of its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close. The chipmaker is expected to earn 65 cents a share, up 41% from a year ago. That would mark a second straight quarter of accelerating growth. Microsemi is working on a potential base.
